But the queen said, ‘I will have the fairies also, that they might be kind and good to our little daughter.’ Now there were thirteen fairies in the kingdom; but as the king and queen had only twelve golden dishes for them to eat out of, they were forced to leave one of the fairies without asking her. So twelve fairies came, each with a high red cap on her head, and red shoes with high heels on her feet, and a long white wand in her hand: and after the feast was over they gathered round in a ring and gave all their best gifts to the little princess. One gave her goodness, another beauty, another riches, and so on till she had all that was good in the world.

events.title: The Thirteenth Fairy's Curse and the Twelfth Fairy's Intervention
detailed_summary: Just as the eleventh fairy concluded her blessing, a significant disturbance was reported from the courtyard, signaling the arrival of the thirteenth fairy, who had not been invited.
This fairy made her entrance into the dining hall, characterized by a black cap, black footwear, and carrying a broomstick.
Incensed by her exclusion from the feast, she severely reprimanded the king and queen and immediately plotted her retribution.
She then proclaimed a curse: the king's daughter, upon reaching her fifteenth year, would suffer an injury from a spindle and consequently die.
At this point, the twelfth of the benevolent fairies, who had yet to bestow her gift, came forward.
She explained that while the malevolent curse was destined to be fulfilled, she possessed the ability to mitigate its harshness.
Her gift, therefore, was to alter the curse so that when the princess was wounded by the spindle, she would not truly perish but instead fall into a profound slumber lasting one hundred years.

events.title: The King's Precaution and the Inevitable Fulfillment of Prophecy
detailed_summary: The king, in a desperate attempt to completely shield his beloved daughter from the prophesied misfortune, issued a decree that all spindles within the kingdom were to be acquired and subsequently destroyed by fire.

Meanwhile, the positive attributes gifted by the initial eleven fairies fully manifested in the princess; she developed into a person of such beauty, grace, goodness, and wisdom that she was adored by everyone acquainted with her.
On the very day she attained the age of fifteen, her parents, the king and queen, were absent from the palace, leaving her by herself.
The princess took the opportunity to wander through the palace, exploring its many rooms and chambers.
Her exploration led her eventually to an ancient tower, accessed by a constricted staircase that terminated at a small door.
A golden key was present in this door; upon turning it, the door swung open, revealing an elderly woman inside, diligently occupied with spinning.
The princess, addressing the woman politely, inquired about her activity, to which the old lady replied she was spinning, nodding and humming as her wheel spun.
Captivated by the motion of the spinning apparatus, the princess expressed her admiration and took the spindle, intending to try spinning herself.
However, almost immediately upon her touching it, the fairy's curse came to pass; the spindle pricked her, and she collapsed to the ground, appearing lifeless.

events.text_segment:
However, the king hoped still to save his dear child altogether from the threatened evil; so he ordered that all the spindles in the kingdom should be bought up and burnt. But all the gifts of the first eleven fairies were in the meantime fulfilled; for the princess was so beautiful, and well behaved, and good, and wise, that everyone who knew her loved her.
It happened that, on the very day she was fifteen years old, the king and queen were not at home, and she was left alone in the palace. So she roved about by herself, and looked at all the rooms and chambers, till at last she came to an old tower, to which there was a narrow staircase ending with a little door. In the door there was a golden key, and when she turned it the door sprang open, and there sat an old lady spinning away very busily. ‘Why, how now, good mother,’ said the princess; ‘what are you doing there?’ ‘Spinning,’ said the old lady, and nodded her head, humming a tune, while buzz! went the wheel. ‘How prettily that little thing turns round!’ said the princess, and took the spindle and began to try and spin. But scarcely had she touched it, before the fairy’s prophecy was fulfilled; the spindle wounded her, and she fell down lifeless on the ground.

events.title: The Enchanted Slumber Descends Upon the Palace
detailed_summary: The princess had not died, but rather had succumbed to a very deep sleep.
The king and queen, who had just arrived back at the palace, along with their entire retinue, also fell into a slumber.
This magical sleep permeated the entire palace grounds: horses dozed in their stalls, dogs slept in the courtyard, pigeons rested on the rooftop, and even flies remained motionless on the walls.

The enchantment extended to inanimate objects as well: the fire in the hearth ceased its burning and appeared to sleep; the mechanism turning the roasting spit stopped, and the spit itself, holding a goose for the king's meal, became still.
The cook, in the midst of pulling a kitchen-boy's hair to reprimand him, was frozen in the act, and both she and the boy fell asleep.
The butler, who was surreptitiously tasting the ale, also fell asleep with the drinking vessel poised at his lips.
In this manner, every person and object within the palace came to a halt and entered a state of profound sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and thus everything stood still, and slept soundly.

Even the fire on the hearth left off blazing, and went to sleep; the jack stopped, and the spit that was turning about with a goose upon it for the king’s dinner stood still; and the cook, who was at that moment pulling the kitchen-boy by the hair to give him a box on the ear for something he had done amiss, let him go, and both fell asleep; the butler, who was slyly tasting the ale, fell asleep with the jug at his lips: and thus everything stood still, and slept soundly.

Round about the castle a hedge of thorns began to grow, which every year became higher and higher, and at last grew close up round the castle and all over it, so that nothing could be seen.

events.title: The Thorn Hedge Encircles the Sleeping Palace
detailed_summary: A substantial barrier of thorns quickly materialized around the palace, growing taller and denser with each passing year.
Ultimately, the historic palace became entirely enveloped and obscured by this thorny growth, so much so that even its roof and chimneys were no longer visible.
Nevertheless, tales of the exquisitely beautiful sleeping princess, who came to be known as Briar Rose, circulated throughout the surrounding lands.
Consequently, over a period of time, several sons of kings were drawn by these accounts and made attempts to force their way through the dense thicket to reach the enchanted palace.
None of these aspirants, however, were ever successful in their endeavors; the thorns and bushes seemed to actively seize them, as if with hands.
These unfortunate princes found themselves trapped fast within the thorny barrier and ultimately met with a miserable demise.

events.title: A Prince Hears the Legend of Briar Rose and Resolves to Find Her
detailed_summary: After a great many years had passed, a king's son journeyed into that particular region.

An elderly man there recounted to him the legend of the impenetrable thorn thicket, detailing how a magnificent palace lay concealed behind it, and within, a marvelous princess named Briar Rose remained in an enchanted sleep along with her entire court.

The old man further conveyed that he had learned from his own grandfather about numerous princes who had previously come and attempted to breach the thicket, but all had become ensnared and perished in their efforts.
Despite these grim accounts, the young prince declared that such stories would not deter him; he was resolved to proceed and see the famed Briar Rose for himself.
The old man made efforts to dissuade the prince from his perilous undertaking, but the prince's determination to go was unshakeable.

events.title: The Prince Arrives as the Century Ends and Enters the Sleeping Palace
detailed_summary: On the very day the prince arrived at the thorny barrier, the century-long enchantment was fated to end.
As he approached, he found not a forbidding wall of thorns but rather an array of beautiful, blooming shrubs, through which he passed without difficulty.
Once he was through, these shrubs closed up behind him, becoming as dense as they had ever been.

He finally arrived at the palace, where he observed the sleeping inhabitants: dogs were asleep in the courtyard, horses stood dormant in the stables, and pigeons rested on the roof, their heads tucked beneath their wings in slumber.
Upon entering the palace itself, he noted flies asleep on the walls.

The roasting spit was motionless; the butler remained frozen with a jug of ale at his lips, about to drink; a maid sat with a chicken in her lap, poised to pluck it; and the cook in the kitchen was still captured with her hand raised, as though she were about to discipline the boy.

events.title: The Awakening Kiss and the Revival of the Palace
detailed_summary: The prince ventured further into the palace, where the silence was so profound he could hear his own respirations.
At last, he reached the old tower and unlatched the door of the small chamber where Briar Rose was located.
There she lay, deeply asleep on a couch near the window, her beauty so captivating he could not avert his gaze.
Overcome by her appearance, he bent down and bestowed a kiss upon her.
The very moment his lips touched hers, Briar Rose's eyes fluttered open, she awoke, and offered him a smile.
Together, they exited the room.
Concurrently, the king and queen also awoke, as did the entire court, all of them looking at one another with immense surprise.
The horses began to move and shake their bodies, the dogs leaped up and barked, and the pigeons lifted their heads from under their wings, surveyed their surroundings, and flew out into the fields.
The flies on the walls resumed their buzzing.
The kitchen fire flared back to life; the roasting jack and the spit began to turn once more, the goose for the king's dinner rotating upon it.
The butler completed his interrupted draught of ale, the maid recommenced plucking the fowl, and the cook finally administered the intended disciplinary rap on the ear to the kitchen boy.

events.title: The Hungry Dog's Plight and the Sparrow's Compassionate Offer
detailed_summary: A dog was neglected by his master and suffered from extreme hunger.
Unable to endure his suffering any longer, the dog fled, feeling deeply sad and sorrowful.
On his journey, he encountered a sparrow who inquired about the cause of his distress.
The dog explained that he was incredibly hungry and had no food.
The sparrow, unconcerned by the scale of the problem, invited the dog to accompany it to a nearby town, promising to secure him ample food.

events.text_segment: A shepherd’s dog had a master who took no care of him, but often let him suffer the greatest hunger. At last he could bear it no longer; so he took to his heels, and off he ran in a very sad and sorrowful mood. On the road he met a sparrow that said to him, ‘Why are you so sad, my friend?’ ‘Because,’ said the dog, ‘I am very very hungry, and have nothing to eat.’ ‘If that be all,’ answered the sparrow, ‘come with me into the next town, and I will soon find you plenty of food.’

events.title: A Feast for the Famished: Sparrow's Ingenuity at the Butcher's and Baker's
detailed_summary: The dog and sparrow journeyed together into the town, and upon passing a butcher's shop, the sparrow advised the dog to wait while it procured some meat.
The sparrow landed on the butcher's shelf and, after carefully checking for observers, dislodged a steak by pecking and scratching at it until it fell.
The dog seized the fallen steak, retreated to a corner, and consumed it entirely.
The sparrow offered to get more, led the dog to another shop, and similarly obtained a second steak for him.
After the dog finished the second piece of meat, the sparrow asked if he had eaten enough.
The dog confirmed he had plenty of meat but now desired some bread.
The sparrow agreed and guided him to a baker’s establishment.
There, the sparrow skillfully pecked at two rolls in the window until they dropped down for the dog.
As the dog still wished for more, the sparrow took him to another bakery and obtained more bread in the same manner.
Once the dog had eaten this additional bread, the sparrow inquired if his hunger was now satisfied.
The dog affirmed that it was and proposed they take a short walk outside the town.

Then the dog snapped it up, and scrambled away with it into a corner, where he soon ate it all up. ‘Well,’ said the sparrow, ‘you shall have some more if you will; so come with me to the next shop, and I will peck you down another steak.’ When the dog had eaten this too, the sparrow said to him, ‘Well, my good friend, have you had enough now?’ ‘I have had plenty of meat,’ answered he, ‘but I should like to have a piece of bread to eat after it.’ ‘Come with me then,’ said the sparrow, ‘and you shall soon have that too.’ So she took him to a baker’s shop, and pecked at two rolls that lay in the window, till they fell down: and as the dog still wished for more, she took him to another shop and pecked down some more for him. When that was eaten, the sparrow asked him whether he had had enough now. ‘Yes,’ said he; ‘and now let us take a walk a little way out of the town.’

events.title: Tragedy on the High Road: The Dog's Death and the Sparrow's Vow
detailed_summary: The two companions set off along the main road, but the warm weather soon made the dog weary, and he expressed a wish to nap.
The sparrow consented, stating it would rest on a nearby bush while the dog slept.
The dog then stretched out on the road and quickly fell into a deep sleep.
While the dog slept, a carter approached with a cart pulled by three horses and carrying two wine casks.
The sparrow observed that the carter was not altering his course and was on a direct path to drive over the sleeping dog.
The sparrow called out, warning the carter to halt or face severe repercussions.
The carter, muttering dismissively about the sparrow's perceived inability to harm him, cracked his whip and proceeded.
He drove his cart directly over the poor dog, the wheels crushing the animal to death.
The sparrow then cried out, accusing the carter, whom it called a cruel villain, of killing its friend.
The sparrow declared that this act of cruelty would cost the carter all his possessions.
The carter, defiant, challenged the sparrow to inflict its worst and continued on his journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So they both went out upon the high road; but as the weather was warm, they had not gone far before the dog said, ‘I am very much tired—I should like to take a nap.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Do your worst, and welcome,’ said the brute, ‘what harm can you do me?’ and passed on.

events.text_segment: So they both went out upon the high road; but as the weather was warm, they had not gone far before the dog said, ‘I am very much tired—I should like to take a nap.’ ‘Very well,’ answered the sparrow, ‘do so, and in the meantime I will perch upon that bush.’ So the dog stretched himself out on the road, and fell fast asleep. Whilst he slept, there came by a carter with a cart drawn by three horses, and loaded with two casks of wine. The sparrow, seeing that the carter did not turn out of the way, but would go on in the track in which the dog lay, so as to drive over him, called out, ‘Stop! stop! Mr Carter, or it shall be the worse for you.’ But the carter, grumbling to himself, ‘You make it the worse for me, indeed! what can you do?’ cracked his whip, and drove his cart over the poor dog, so that the wheels crushed him to death. ‘There,’ cried the sparrow, ‘thou cruel villain, thou hast killed my friend the dog. Now mind what I say. This deed of thine shall cost thee all thou art worth.’ ‘Do your worst, and welcome,’ said the brute, ‘what harm can you do me?’ and passed on.

events.title: Retribution Begins: The Sparrow Dismantles the Carter's Cart and Horses
detailed_summary: The sparrow concealed itself beneath the cart's covering and pecked at the bung of one of the wine casks until it became loose.
Consequently, all the wine drained out from the cask without the carter immediately noticing.
Eventually, the carter looked back and saw his cart dripping and one cask entirely empty, leading him to exclaim his misfortune.
The sparrow then appeared, alighting on one of the horse's heads, and retorted that the carter was not yet wretched enough, proceeding to peck the horse until it reared and kicked.
Witnessing this, the carter retrieved his hatchet and aimed a blow at the sparrow, intending to kill it.
The sparrow, however, flew away, and the carter's strike fatally hit the horse on its head.
The carter lamented his ill luck once more, to which the sparrow responded that he was still not sufficiently wretched.
As the carter moved on with his remaining two horses, the sparrow again slipped under the cart's canvas.
It pecked out the bung of the second wine cask, causing all its contents to spill out.
When the carter discovered this new loss, he again cried out about his miserable state.
The sparrow countered that he was not wretched enough yet, then landed on the second horse's head and started pecking it.
The carter ran towards the sparrow and swung his hatchet again; the bird dodged, and the blow fell upon the second horse, killing it instantly.
The carter bemoaned his unlucky fate, and the sparrow repeated its taunting refrain.
The sparrow then perched upon the third horse and commenced pecking it as well.
The carter, now mad with fury and acting recklessly, struck at the sparrow again but ended up killing his third horse, just as he had the other two.
The carter cried out in his misery, and the sparrow, flying off, declared that he was not yet wretched enough and that it would now bring plague and punishment to his own house.

When the carter saw this, he again cried out, ‘Miserable wretch that I am!’ But the sparrow answered, ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ and perched on the head of the second horse, and pecked at him too. The carter ran up and struck at her again with his hatchet; but away she flew, and the blow fell upon the second horse and killed him on the spot. ‘Unlucky wretch that I am!’ said he. ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ said the sparrow; and perching upon the third horse, she began to peck him too. The carter was mad with fury; and without looking about him, or caring what he was about, struck again at the sparrow; but killed his third horse as he done the other two. ‘Alas! miserable wretch that I am!’ cried he. ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ answered the sparrow as she flew away; ‘now will I plague and punish thee at thy own house.’

events.title: Retribution at Home: The Sparrow and a Swarm Devour the Carter's Corn
detailed_summary: Compelled to abandon his cart, the carter returned home, overwhelmed with rage and vexation.
He recounted his misfortunes to his wife, detailing the spilled wine and the death of all three horses.
His wife, in turn, informed him that a malevolent bird had entered their house, bringing with it what seemed like every bird in existence.
She reported that this avian horde was in their loft, rapidly devouring their stored corn.
The husband rushed upstairs and witnessed thousands of birds on the floor consuming his grain, with the familiar sparrow in their midst.
Seeing that almost all his corn was gone, the carter cried out in despair about his wretched state.
The sparrow retorted that he was still not wretched enough and forewarned that his cruelty would ultimately cost him his life, before flying away.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ said the sparrow; ‘thy cruelty shall cost thee thy life yet!’ and away she flew.

events.text_segment: The carter was forced at last to leave his cart behind him, and to go home overflowing with rage and vexation. ‘Alas!’ said he to his wife, ‘what ill luck has befallen me!—my wine is all spilt, and my horses all three dead.’ ‘Alas! husband,’ replied she, ‘and a wicked bird has come into the house, and has brought with her all the birds in the world, I am sure, and they have fallen upon our corn in the loft, and are eating it up at such a rate!’ Away ran the husband upstairs, and saw thousands of birds sitting upon the floor eating up his corn, with the sparrow in the midst of them. ‘Unlucky wretch that I am!’ cried the carter; for he saw that the corn was almost all gone. ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ said the sparrow; ‘thy cruelty shall cost thee thy life yet!’ and away she flew.

events.title: The Sparrow's Final Taunt and the Carter's Fatal Rage
detailed_summary: The carter, having witnessed the loss of all his possessions, descended to his kitchen, still showing no remorse for his actions, and sat angrily in the chimney corner.
The sparrow positioned itself outside the window and cried out that the carter's cruelty would cost him his life.
In a fit of rage, the carter sprang up, seized his hatchet, and hurled it at the sparrow.
The hatchet missed the bird but shattered the windowpane.
The sparrow then hopped inside, perched upon the window-seat, and repeated its dire warning about the cost of the carter's life.
Driven mad and blind with fury, the carter struck the window-seat with such force that he split it in two.

As the sparrow darted from place to place within the room, the carter and his wife, in their furious attempts to strike it, ended up breaking all their furniture, glassware, and even damaging the walls, without managing to touch the bird.
Ultimately, however, they succeeded in capturing the sparrow.
The wife inquired if she should kill it immediately.
The carter, desiring a more agonizing end for the bird, declared that merely killing it was too lenient and that he would eat it instead.
The sparrow began to flutter and stretch its neck, crying out one final time that the carter's cruelty would yet cost him his life.
Unable to delay any longer, the carter handed his wife the hatchet and commanded her to strike the bird and kill it while he held it in his hand.
The wife swung the hatchet, but her aim was errant; she missed the sparrow and instead struck her husband on the head.
The carter fell down dead, and the sparrow flew serenely back to its nest.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the wife struck; but she missed her aim, and hit her husband on the head so that he fell down dead, and the sparrow flew quietly home to her nest.

events.text_segment: The carter seeing that he had thus lost all that he had, went down into his kitchen; and was still not sorry for what he had done, but sat himself angrily and sulkily in the chimney corner. But the sparrow sat on the outside of the window, and cried ‘Carter! thy cruelty shall cost thee thy life!’ With that he jumped up in a rage, seized his hatchet, and threw it at the sparrow; but it missed her, and only broke the window. The sparrow now hopped in, perched upon the window-seat, and cried, ‘Carter! it shall cost thee thy life!’ Then he became mad and blind with rage, and struck the window-seat with such force that he cleft it in two: and as the sparrow flew from place to place, the carter and his wife were so furious, that they broke all their furniture, glasses, chairs, benches, the table, and at last the walls, without touching the bird at all. In the end, however, they caught her: and the wife said, ‘Shall I kill her at once?’ ‘No,’ cried he, ‘that is letting her off too easily: she shall die a much more cruel death; I will eat her.’ But the sparrow began to flutter about, and stretch out her neck and cried, ‘Carter! it shall cost thee thy life yet!’ With that he could wait no longer: so he gave his wife the hatchet, and cried, ‘Wife, strike at the bird and kill her in my hand.’ And the wife struck; but she missed her aim, and hit her husband on the head so that he fell down dead, and the sparrow flew quietly home to her nest.

events.title: The King's Perplexing Problem and a Deadly Challenge
detailed_summary: A king was troubled because his twelve daughters, despite being locked in their room each night, awoke every morning with their shoes completely worn out, as if they had danced extensively.
The origin of their nightly excursions and the cause of the worn shoes remained an unsolved puzzle.
To uncover this secret, the king issued a proclamation across his realm.
He promised that any man who could reveal where the princesses danced would win the hand of his chosen daughter in marriage and be designated as the successor to the throne.
However, the proclamation carried a dire warning: any contender who failed to solve the mystery within three days and nights would face execution.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a king who had twelve beautiful daughters.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: but whoever tried and did not succeed, after three days and nights, should be put to death.

events.text_segment:
There was a king who had twelve beautiful daughters. They slept in twelve beds all in one room; and when they went to bed, the doors were shut and locked up; but every morning their shoes were found to be quite worn through as if they had been danced in all night; and yet nobody could find out how it happened, or where they had been.
Then the king made it known to all the land, that if any person could discover the secret, and find out where it was that the princesses danced in the night, he should have the one he liked best for his wife, and should be king after his death; but whoever tried and did not succeed, after three days and nights, should be put to death.

events.title: Failed Suitors and a Soldier's Chance Encounter with Magical Aid
detailed_summary: A prince was the first to accept the king's challenge, receiving good hospitality and being placed in a room adjacent to the princesses' chamber to observe them, with his door left open.
Despite these arrangements, the prince succumbed to sleep and, upon waking, found the princesses' shoes worn out, indicating they had danced.
This pattern repeated for two more nights, leading to the prince's execution by the king's order.
Several other hopefuls followed, but all met the same unfortunate end, losing their lives after failing to uncover the secret.
Subsequently, an old soldier, unable to fight due to battle wounds, journeyed through the king's land.
While traveling in a forest, he met an elderly woman who inquired about his destination.
The soldier confessed his uncertainty but expressed an interest in discovering the princesses' dancing secret, hoping it might lead him to become king.
The old woman assured him the task was not overly difficult, offering crucial advice: he must avoid drinking any wine offered by a princess in the evening and then feign deep sleep.
She also provided him with a special cloak, explaining that wearing it would render him invisible, allowing him to follow the princesses undetected.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A king’s son soon came.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she gave him a cloak, and said, ‘As soon as you put that on you will become invisible, and you will then be able to follow the princesses wherever they go.’

events.text_segment:
A king’s son soon came. He was well entertained, and in the evening was taken to the chamber next to the one where the princesses lay in their twelve beds. There he was to sit and watch where they went to dance; and, in order that nothing might pass without his hearing it, the door of his chamber was left open. But the king’s son soon fell asleep; and when he awoke in the morning he found that the princesses had all been dancing, for the soles of their shoes were full of holes. The same thing happened the second and third night: so the king ordered his head to be cut off. After him came several others; but they had all the same luck, and all lost their lives in the same manner.
Now it chanced that an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, passed through the country where this king reigned: and as he was travelling through a wood, he met an old woman, who asked him where he was going. ‘I hardly know where I am going, or what I had better do,’ said the soldier; ‘but I think I should like very well to find out where it is that the princesses dance, and then in time I might be a king.’ ‘Well,’ said the old dame, ‘that is no very hard task: only take care not to drink any of the wine which one of the princesses will bring to you in the evening; and as soon as she leaves you pretend to be fast asleep.’
Then she gave him a cloak, and said, ‘As soon as you put that on you will become invisible, and you will then be able to follow the princesses wherever they go.’

events.title: The Soldier's Strategic Deception and the Princesses' Preparations
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the old woman's counsel, the soldier resolved to test his fortune and presented himself to the king, declaring his readiness to undertake the challenge.
He received the same courteous treatment as previous suitors, and the king provided him with fine royal attire.
As evening arrived, he was escorted to the antechamber.
Just before he intended to lie down, the eldest princess approached him with a cup of wine.
The soldier, remembering the old woman's warning, discreetly disposed of the wine without consuming any.
He then settled on his bed and soon began to snore loudly, convincingly simulating deep sleep.
The twelve princesses, hearing his snores, were amused, and the eldest remarked that he, like others before him, could have chosen a wiser path than risking his life.
They then got up, opened their storage, retrieved their elegant clothing, adorned themselves before mirrors, and moved about excitedly, eager for their nightly activity.
However, the youngest princess voiced a sense of unease amidst her sisters' happiness, fearing some misfortune.

The eldest dismissed her concerns, calling her a simpleton and reminding her of the many princes who had failed to discover their secret, adding that the soldier would have slept soundly even without the drugged wine she presumed he drank.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the soldier heard all this good counsel, he determined to try his luck: so he went to the king, and said he was willing to undertake the task.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And as for this soldier, even if I had not given him his sleeping draught, he would have slept soundly enough.’

events.text_segment:
When the soldier heard all this good counsel, he determined to try his luck: so he went to the king, and said he was willing to undertake the task.
He was as well received as the others had been, and the king ordered fine royal robes to be given him; and when the evening came he was led to the outer chamber. Just as he was going to lie down, the eldest of the princesses brought him a cup of wine; but the soldier threw it all away secretly, taking care not to drink a drop. Then he laid himself down on his bed, and in a little while began to snore very loud as if he was fast asleep. When the twelve princesses heard this they laughed heartily; and the eldest said, ‘This fellow too might have done a wiser thing than lose his life in this way!’ Then they rose up and opened their drawers and boxes, and took out all their fine clothes, and dressed themselves at the glass, and skipped about as if they were eager to begin dancing. But the youngest said, ‘I don’t know how it is, while you are so happy I feel very uneasy; I am sure some mischance will befall us.’ ‘You simpleton,’ said the eldest, ‘you are always afraid; have you forgotten how many kings’ sons have already watched in vain? And as for this soldier, even if I had not given him his sleeping draught, he would have slept soundly enough.’

events.title: Unveiling the Hidden Passage and the Silver Grove
detailed_summary: Once fully prepared, the princesses observed the soldier, who continued to snore without moving, convincing them of their safety.
The eldest princess then went to her bed, clapped her hands, causing the bed to lower into the floor and reveal a trapdoor.
The soldier witnessed them descend through the opening one by one, with the eldest leading.
Realizing he needed to act quickly, he got up, donned the invisibility cloak given by the old woman, and followed.
While on the stairs, he inadvertently stepped on the gown of the youngest princess.
She exclaimed to her sisters that something was amiss, feeling someone tug her gown.
The eldest princess dismissed her alarm, casually suggesting it was merely a nail in the wall.
They all continued downwards and emerged at the bottom into a beautiful grove where all the tree leaves were made of silver, shimmering splendidly.
The soldier, wanting a memento, broke off a small silver branch, which caused a loud sound to emanate from the tree.
The youngest princess again expressed her conviction that something was wrong, questioning if her sisters heard the noise, which she noted had never occurred before.
The eldest, however, reassured them by claiming it was only their awaiting princes shouting in joyful anticipation of their arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When they were all ready, they went and looked at the soldier; but he snored on, and did not stir hand or foot: so they thought they were quite safe; and the eldest went up to her own bed and clapped her hands, and the bed sank into the floor and a trap-door flew open.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But the eldest said, ‘It is only our princes, who are shouting for joy at our approach.’

events.text_segment: When they were all ready, they went and looked at the soldier; but he snored on, and did not stir hand or foot: so they thought they were quite safe; and the eldest went up to her own bed and clapped her hands, and the bed sank into the floor and a trap-door flew open. The soldier saw them going down through the trap-door one after another, the eldest leading the way; and thinking he had no time to lose, he jumped up, put on the cloak which the old woman had given him, and followed them; but in the middle of the stairs he trod on the gown of the youngest princess, and she cried out to her sisters, ‘All is not right; someone took hold of my gown.’ ‘You silly creature!’ said the eldest, ‘it is nothing but a nail in the wall.’ Then down they all went, and at the bottom they found themselves in a most delightful grove of trees; and the leaves were all of silver, and glittered and sparkled beautifully. The soldier wished to take away some token of the place; so he broke off a little branch, and there came a loud noise from the tree. Then the youngest daughter said again, ‘I am sure all is not right—did not you hear that noise? That never happened before.’ But the eldest said, ‘It is only our princes, who are shouting for joy at our approach.’

events.title: Traversing More Magical Groves and Reaching the Lakeside Rendezvous
detailed_summary: The group proceeded to a second grove where the leaves were entirely of gold.
Following that, they entered a third grove, its leaves made of sparkling diamonds.
From each of these groves, the soldier broke off a branch as a token.
Each time he did so, a loud noise occurred, causing the youngest sister to tremble with fear.
The eldest sister consistently attributed these sounds to the princes exclaiming with joy.
Their journey continued until they arrived at a large lake.
By the lake's edge, twelve small boats were waiting, each occupied by a handsome prince, apparently expecting the princesses.
One princess boarded each boat, and the invisible soldier chose to enter the boat carrying the youngest princess.
While they were being rowed across the lake, the prince in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier commented on the unusual difficulty in rowing.
He noted that despite his efforts, their progress was slower than normal and he felt quite tired, remarking that the boat seemed exceptionally heavy that day.
The youngest princess attributed his struggle to the warmth of the weather, saying she also felt very warm.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘It is only the heat of the weather,’ said the princess: ‘I feel it very warm too.’

events.title: The Secret Ball, Unexplained Incidents, and the Journey Back
detailed_summary: Across the lake, they saw a splendid, brightly lit castle from which joyous music of horns and trumpets emanated.
Everyone disembarked and entered the castle, where each prince began dancing with his designated princess.
The soldier, still invisible, joined in the dancing as well.
Whenever a princess had a cup of wine placed beside her, the soldier would drink it entirely, so that the cup was empty when she lifted it to her lips.
This phenomenon particularly terrified the youngest sister, but the eldest continually quieted her.
The dancing continued until three o'clock in the morning, by which time all their shoes were completely worn through, forcing them to stop.
The princes then rowed them back across the lake; for this return trip, the soldier positioned himself in the boat with the eldest princess.

events.title: The Truth Unveiled, the Princesses' Confession, and the Soldier's Reward
detailed_summary: When the appointed time arrived for the soldier to disclose the secret, he was brought before the king, carrying the three branches and the golden cup as proof.

The soldier, explaining that he was no longer very young, selected the eldest princess.

events.title: The Fisherman's Encounter with the Enchanted Fish
detailed_summary: A fisherman and his wife reside in a humble pigsty near the sea.
While fishing, the man catches a large fish which, to his surprise, speaks.
The fish reveals itself to be an enchanted prince and implores the fisherman to release it.

events.text_segment: There was once a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside. The fisherman used to go out all day long a-fishing; and one day, as he sat on the shore with his rod, looking at the sparkling waves and watching his line, all on a sudden his float was dragged away deep into the water: and in drawing it up he pulled out a great fish. But the fish said, ‘Pray let me live! I am not a real fish; I am an enchanted prince: put me in the water again, and let me go!’ ‘Oh, ho!’ said the man, ‘you need not make so many words about the matter; I will have nothing to do with a fish that can talk: so swim away, sir, as soon as you please!’ Then he put him back into the water, and the fish darted straight down to the bottom, and left a long streak of blood behind him on the wave.

detailed_summary: Upon returning home, the fisherman recounts his extraordinary catch and its release to his wife, Ilsabill.
Ilsabill chastises him for not requesting anything from the magical creature, lamenting their squalid living conditions.

events.text_segment:
When the fisherman went home to his wife in the pigsty, he told her how he had caught a great fish, and how it had told him it was an enchanted prince, and how, on hearing it speak, he had let it go again. ‘Did not you ask it for anything?’ said the wife, ‘we live very wretchedly here, in this nasty dirty pigsty; do go back and tell the fish we want a snug little cottage.’
The fisherman did not much like the business: however, he went to the seashore; and when he came back there the water looked all yellow and green. And he stood at the water’s edge, and said:
‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
Then the fish came swimming to him, and said, ‘Well, what is her will? What does your wife want?’ ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘she says that when I had caught you, I ought to have asked you for something before I let you go; she does not like living any longer in the pigsty, and wants a snug little cottage.’ ‘Go home, then,’ said the fish; ‘she is in the cottage already!’ So the man went home, and saw his wife standing at the door of a nice trim little cottage. ‘Come in, come in!’ said she; ‘is not this much better than the filthy pigsty we had?’ And there was a parlour, and a bedchamber, and a kitchen; and behind the cottage there was a little garden, planted with all sorts of flowers and fruits; and there was a courtyard behind, full of ducks and chickens. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘how happily we shall live now!’ ‘We will try to do so, at least,’ said his wife.

The fisherman expresses his unwillingness, fearing the fish might become angry and stating they should be content with the cottage.

With a heavy heart, the fisherman approaches the sea, which now appears blue and gloomy, though calm.
He recites the verse to summon the fish.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Everything went right for a week or two, and then Dame Ilsabill said, ‘Husband, there is not near room enough for us in this cottage; the courtyard and the garden are a great deal too small; I should like to have a large stone castle to live in: go to the fish again and tell him to give us a castle.’

events.text_segment:
Everything went right for a week or two, and then Dame Ilsabill said, ‘Husband, there is not near room enough for us in this cottage; the courtyard and the garden are a great deal too small; I should like to have a large stone castle to live in: go to the fish again and tell him to give us a castle.’ ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘I don’t like to go to him again, for perhaps he will be angry; we ought to be easy with this pretty cottage to live in.’ ‘Nonsense!’ said the wife; ‘he will do it very willingly, I know; go along and try!’
The fisherman went, but his heart was very heavy: and when he came to the sea, it looked blue and gloomy, though it was very calm; and he went close to the edge of the waves, and said:
 ‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘Well, what does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the man, dolefully, ‘my wife wants to live in a stone castle.’ ‘Go home, then,’ said the fish; ‘she is standing at the gate of it already.’ So away went the fisherman, and found his wife standing before the gate of a great castle. ‘See,’ said she, ‘is not this grand?’ With that they went into the castle together, and found a great many servants there, and the rooms all richly furnished, and full of golden chairs and tables; and behind the castle was a garden, and around it was a park half a mile long, full of sheep, and goats, and hares, and deer; and in the courtyard were stables and cow-houses. ‘Well,’ said the man, ‘now we will live cheerful and happy in this beautiful castle for the rest of our lives.’ ‘Perhaps we may,’ said the wife; ‘but let us sleep upon it, before we make up our minds to that.’ So they went to bed.

events.text_segment:
The next morning when Dame Ilsabill awoke it was broad daylight, and she jogged the fisherman with her elbow, and said, ‘Get up, husband, and bestir yourself, for we must be king of all the land.’ ‘Wife, wife,’ said the man, ‘why should we wish to be the king? I will not be king.’ ‘Then I will,’ said she. ‘But, wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘how can you be king—the fish cannot make you a king?’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘say no more about it, but go and try! I will be king.’ So the man went away quite sorrowful to think that his wife should want to be king. This time the sea looked a dark grey colour, and was overspread with curling waves and the ridges of foam as he cried out:
 ‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘Well, what would she have now?’ said the fish. ‘Alas!’ said the poor man, ‘my wife wants to be king.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is king already.’

events.text_segment:
Then the fisherman went home; and as he came close to the palace he saw a troop of soldiers, and heard the sound of drums and trumpets. And when he went in he saw his wife sitting on a throne of gold and diamonds, with a golden crown upon her head; and on each side of her stood six fair maidens, each a head taller than the other. ‘Well, wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘are you king?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am king.’ And when he had looked at her for a long time, he said, ‘Ah, wife! what a fine thing it is to be king! Now we shall never have anything more to wish for as long as we live.’ ‘I don’t know how that may be,’ said she; ‘never is a long time. I am king, it is true; but I begin to be tired of that, and I think I should like to be emperor.’ ‘Alas, wife! why should you wish to be emperor?’ said the fisherman. ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘go to the fish! I say I will be emperor.’ ‘Ah, wife!’ replied the fisherman, ‘the fish cannot make an emperor, I am sure, and I should not like to ask him for such a thing.’ ‘I am king,’ said Ilsabill, ‘and you are my slave; so go at once!’
So the fisherman was forced to go; and he muttered as he went along, ‘This will come to no good, it is too much to ask; the fish will be tired at last, and then we shall be sorry for what we have done.’ He soon came to the seashore; and the water was quite black and muddy, and a mighty whirlwind blew over the waves and rolled them about, but he went as near as he could to the water’s brink, and said:

  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘What would she have now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘she wants to be emperor.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is emperor already.’

So he went home again; and as he came near he saw his wife Ilsabill sitting on a very lofty throne made of solid gold, with a great crown on her head full two yards high; and on each side of her stood her guards and attendants in a row, each one smaller than the other, from the tallest giant down to a little dwarf no bigger than my finger. And before her stood princes, and dukes, and earls: and the fisherman went up to her and said, ‘Wife, are you emperor?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am emperor.’ ‘Ah!’ said the man, as he gazed upon her, ‘what a fine thing it is to be emperor!’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘why should we stop at being emperor? I will be pope next.’ ‘O wife, wife!’ said he, ‘how can you be pope? there is but one pope at a time in Christendom.’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘I will be pope this very day.’ ‘But,’ replied the husband, ‘the fish cannot make you pope.’ ‘What nonsense!’ said she; ‘if he can make an emperor, he can make a pope: go and try him.’
So the fisherman went. But when he came to the shore the wind was raging and the sea was tossed up and down in boiling waves, and the ships were in trouble, and rolled fearfully upon the tops of the billows. In the middle of the heavens there was a little piece of blue sky, but towards the south all was red, as if a dreadful storm was rising. At this sight the fisherman was dreadfully frightened, and he trembled so that his knees knocked together: but still he went down near to the shore, and said:
‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘What does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘my wife wants to be pope.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is pope already.’

events.title: The Final Overreach and Return to the Pigsty
detailed_summary: The fisherman returns to find Ilsabill on a throne two miles high, adorned with three great crowns, and surrounded by the full power and pageantry of the Church, including rows of massive burning lights.
He confirms her status as pope and suggests she must now be content, as there is nothing greater to become.
Ilsabill cryptically replies that she will consider it.
That night, she cannot sleep, consumed by thoughts of what she could be next.
As dawn breaks and the sun rises, she is struck by the realization that she cannot control its rising, which infuriates her.
She rouses her husband, demanding he tell the fish that she must become lord of the sun and moon.
The fisherman, so startled and frightened by this demand that he falls out of bed, questions her inability to be satisfied with being pope.
Ilsabill insists, claiming she feels uneasy as long as the celestial bodies operate without her command.

Shivering with terror, the man makes his way to the shore. A dreadful storm has erupted, shaking trees and rocks. The sky is black with storm clouds, lightning flashes, and thunder roars. The sea is filled with enormous black waves, like mountains crowned with white foam.
He manages to cry out his verse to the fish.
The fish asks what she desires now.
The fisherman relays her wish to be lord of the sun and moon.
The fish responds by telling him to go home to their pigsty again.
And so, they returned to their original humble dwelling, where they continue to live.

events.text_segment:
Then the fisherman went home, and found Ilsabill sitting on a throne that was two miles high. And she had three great crowns on her head, and around her stood all the pomp and power of the Church. And on each side of her were two rows of burning lights, of all sizes, the greatest as large as the highest and biggest tower in the world, and the least no larger than a small rushlight. ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, as he looked at all this greatness, ‘are you pope?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am pope.’ ‘Well, wife,’ replied he, ‘it is a grand thing to be pope; and now you must be easy, for you can be nothing greater.’ ‘I will think about that,’ said the wife. Then they went to bed: but Dame Ilsabill could not sleep all night for thinking what she should be next. At last, as she was dropping asleep, morning broke, and the sun rose. ‘Ha!’ thought she, as she woke up and looked at it through the window, ‘after all I cannot prevent the sun rising.’ At this thought she was very angry, and wakened her husband, and said, ‘Husband, go to the fish and tell him I must be lord of the sun and moon.’ The fisherman was half asleep, but the thought frightened him so much that he started and fell out of bed. ‘Alas, wife!’ said he, ‘cannot you be easy with being pope?’ ‘No,’ said she, ‘I am very uneasy as long as the sun and moon rise without my leave. Go to the fish at once!’
Then the man went shivering with fear; and as he was going down to the shore a dreadful storm arose, so that the trees and the very rocks shook. And all the heavens became black with stormy clouds, and the lightnings played, and the thunders rolled; and you might have seen in the sea great black waves, swelling up like mountains with crowns of white foam upon their heads. And the fisherman crept towards the sea, and cried out, as well as he could:
‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘What does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said he, ‘she wants to be lord of the sun and moon.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish, ‘to your pigsty again.’
And there they live to this very day.

events.title: The Bear's Disrespectful Visit and Insult to the Wrens
detailed_summary: While walking in the forest, the bear becomes captivated by a bird's beautiful singing.
The wolf identifies the singer as the King of birds, the willow-wren, and states that they must show reverence.
The bear expresses a keen interest in seeing the willow-wren's royal palace, prompting the wolf to advise him to wait until the Queen wren makes an appearance.
Soon after, the Queen arrives with food, accompanied by the King, and they begin feeding their young.
The bear is eager to approach, but the wolf restrains him, advising they wait until the royal couple departs.
They observe the location of the nest and then leave.
Unable to contain his curiosity, the bear returns to the nest alone a short time later, when the King and Queen have flown out.
He peeps into the nest and sees five or six young wrens.
The bear mockingly questions if this is the royal palace, calling it a 'wretched palace' and deriding the young birds as 'disreputable children' instead of royal offspring.
The young wrens react with extreme anger to the insult, vehemently denying the accusations, asserting the honesty of their parents, and warning the bear that he will be made to pay for his words.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the young wrens heard that, they were frightfully angry, and screamed: ‘No, that we are not! Our parents are honest people! Bear, you will have to pay for that!’

events.text_segment: Once in summer-time the bear and the wolf were walking in the forest, and the bear heard a bird singing so beautifully that he said: ‘Brother wolf, what bird is it that sings so well?’ ‘That is the King of birds,’ said the wolf, ‘before whom we must bow down.’ In reality the bird was the willow-wren. ‘IF that’s the case,’ said the bear, ‘I should very much like to see his royal palace; come, take me thither.’ ‘That is not done quite as you seem to think,’ said the wolf; ‘you must wait until the Queen comes,’ Soon afterwards, the Queen arrived with some food in her beak, and the lord King came too, and they began to feed their young ones. The bear would have liked to go at once, but the wolf held him back by the sleeve, and said: ‘No, you must wait until the lord and lady Queen have gone away again.’ So they took stock of the hole where the nest lay, and trotted away. The bear, however, could not rest until he had seen the royal palace, and when a short time had passed, went to it again. The King and Queen had just flown out, so he peeped in and saw five or six young ones lying there. ‘Is that the royal palace?’ cried the bear; ‘it is a wretched palace, and you are not King’s children, you are disreputable children!’ When the young wrens heard that, they were frightfully angry, and screamed: ‘No, that we are not! Our parents are honest people! Bear, you will have to pay for that!’

events.title: The Wrens' Outrage and the Declaration of War
detailed_summary: The bear and the wolf become apprehensive and retreat to their respective dens.
The young willow-wrens continue their distressed cries and, when their parents return with food, they adamantly refuse to eat.
They declare they will not touch even a fly's leg, even if starving, until their parents settle the matter of their respectability, informing them of the bear's insulting visit.
The old King wren reassures his children, promising that the bear will be punished for his actions.
He and the Queen immediately fly to the bear's cave and call in to him.
The King wren, addressing the bear as 'Old Growler,' demands to know why he insulted his children and declares that he will suffer for it through a 'bloody war.'
With war thus declared upon the Bear, all four-footed animals, including oxen, asses, cows, deer, and every other terrestrial creature, are summoned to participate.
Simultaneously, the willow-wren summons all creatures that fly, not only birds of all sizes but also midges, hornets, bees, and flies, to join his forces.

events.text_segment: The bear and the wolf grew uneasy, and turned back and went into their holes. The young willow-wrens, however, continued to cry and scream, and when their parents again brought food they said: ‘We will not so much as touch one fly’s leg, no, not if we were dying of hunger, until you have settled whether we are respectable children or not; the bear has been here and has insulted us!’ Then the old King said: ‘Be easy, he shall be punished,’ and he at once flew with the Queen to the bear’s cave, and called in: ‘Old Growler, why have you insulted my children? You shall suffer for it—we will punish you by a bloody war.’ Thus war was announced to the Bear, and all four-footed animals were summoned to take part in it, oxen, asses, cows, deer, and every other animal the earth contained. And the willow-wren summoned everything which flew in the air, not only birds, large and small, but midges, and hornets, bees and flies had to come.

events.title: Espionage Reveals the Enemy's Battle Strategy
detailed_summary: When the time for war to commence drew near, the willow-wren dispatched spies to ascertain the identity of the enemy's commander-in-chief.
The gnat, described as the most cunning spy, flew into the forest where the enemy forces were assembled.
The gnat concealed itself beneath a leaf on the tree where the password and strategic commands were to be issued.
The bear was present and called the fox before him, appointing the fox as general due to his reputation as the most cunning of all animals.
The fox accepted the position of general and then questioned what signal they should agree upon for their maneuvers.
As no one had a suggestion, the fox proposed using his own long, bushy tail, which resembled a plume of red feathers, as the signal.
He explained that if he lifted his tail high, it meant all was going well, and the troops should charge; however, if he let it hang down, they should retreat as quickly as possible.
Having overheard this critical information, the gnat flew back and meticulously reported every detail to the willow-wren.

There stood the bear, and he called the fox before him and said: ‘Fox, you are the most cunning of all animals, you shall be general and lead us.’ ‘Good,’ said the fox, ‘but what signal shall we agree upon?’ No one knew that, so the fox said: ‘I have a fine long bushy tail, which almost looks like a plume of red feathers. When I lift my tail up quite high, all is going well, and you must charge; but if I let it hang down, run away as fast as you can.’ When the gnat had heard that, she flew away again, and revealed everything, down to the minutest detail, to the willow-wren.

events.title: The Decisive Battle: The Hornet's Sting and the Birds' Victory
detailed_summary: At daybreak, as the battle was set to begin, the assembled four-footed animals charged forward, creating a noise so immense that the earth trembled.
The willow-wren, accompanied by his aerial army, also advanced, their movement generating such a humming, whirring, and swarming that it caused unease and fear in all observers.
Both armies moved to engage each other.
The willow-wren issued an order to the hornet, instructing it to position itself beneath the fox's tail and sting with all its might.
When the fox experienced the first sting, he jolted and lifted one leg in pain but managed to endure it, keeping his tail held high.
Upon receiving a second sting, the fox was compelled to lower his tail for a moment.
After the third sting, the fox could no longer bear the pain; he screamed and tucked his tail between his legs.
Witnessing this, the other animals misinterpreted the fox's lowered tail as the signal for retreat, concluded that all was lost, and began to flee, each seeking refuge in its hole.
As a result, the birds emerged victorious from the battle.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the animals saw that, they thought all was lost, and began to flee, each into his hole, and the birds had won the battle.

events.text_segment: When day broke, and the battle was to begin, all the four-footed animals came running up with such a noise that the earth trembled. The willow-wren with his army also came flying through the air with such a humming, and whirring, and swarming that every one was uneasy and afraid, and on both sides they advanced against each other. But the willow-wren sent down the hornet, with orders to settle beneath the fox’s tail, and sting with all his might. When the fox felt the first string, he started so that he lifted one leg, from pain, but he bore it, and still kept his tail high in the air; at the second sting, he was forced to put it down for a moment; at the third, he could hold out no longer, screamed, and put his tail between his legs. When the animals saw that, they thought all was lost, and began to flee, each into his hole, and the birds had won the battle.

events.title: The Bear's Apology and the Wrens' Final Triumph
detailed_summary: Following the victory, the King and Queen wren flew home to their children, joyfully exclaiming, 'Children, rejoice, eat and drink to your heart's content, we have won the battle!'
However, the young wrens maintained their resolve, stating they would not eat yet.
They insisted that the bear must first come to their nest, beg for their pardon, and explicitly affirm that they are 'honourable children' before they would consider eating.
In response, the willow-wren (King) flew to the bear's hole.
He sternly addressed the bear, 'Growler, you are to come to the nest to my children, and beg their pardon, or else every rib of your body shall be broken.'
Gripped by immense fear, the bear crept to the wrens' nest and formally begged their pardon.
Finally satisfied, the young wrens at last sat down together, ate, drank, and celebrated merrily late into the night.

events.title: The Lost Ball and the Frog's Conditional Offer
detailed_summary: A young princess, during a solitary walk in a wood, sits by a cool spring to rest.
She plays with her favorite golden ball, tossing it in the air, but eventually throws it too high and it falls into the spring.
The princess is distraught as the spring is too deep to see the bottom, and she laments her loss, offering all her possessions for the ball's return.
A frog emerges from the water and inquires about her sorrow.
The princess dismissively explains her predicament to the 'nasty frog'.
The frog expresses no interest in her clothes or jewels but offers to retrieve the ball if she promises to love him, let him live with her, eat from her plate, and sleep in her bed.
The princess privately scoffs at the frog's conditions, believing he could never leave the spring, and agrees to his terms solely to recover her ball.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So she said to the frog, ‘Well, if you will bring me my ball, I will do all you ask.’

events.text_segment:
One fine evening a young princess put on her bonnet and clogs, and went out to take a walk by herself in a wood; and when she came to a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it, she sat herself down to rest a while. Now she had a golden ball in her hand, which was her favourite plaything; and she was always tossing it up into the air, and catching it again as it fell. After a time she threw it up so high that she missed catching it as it fell; and the ball bounded away, and rolled along upon the ground, till at last it fell down into the spring. The princess looked into the spring after her ball, but it was very deep, so deep that she could not see the bottom of it. Then she began to bewail her loss, and said, ‘Alas! if I could only get my ball again, I would give all my fine clothes and jewels, and everything that I have in the world.’
Whilst she was speaking, a frog put its head out of the water, and said, ‘Princess, why do you weep so bitterly?’ ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘what can you do for me, you nasty frog? My golden ball has fallen into the spring.’ The frog said, ‘I want not your pearls, and jewels, and fine clothes; but if you will love me, and let me live with you and eat from off your golden plate, and sleep upon your bed, I will bring you your ball again.’ ‘What nonsense,’ thought the princess, ‘this silly frog is talking! He can never even get out of the spring to visit me, though he may be able to get my ball for me, and therefore I will tell him he shall have what he asks.’ So she said to the frog, ‘Well, if you will bring me my ball, I will do all you ask.’

The princess, ecstatic to see her ball, quickly picks it up.

events.title: The Frog's Arrival and the King's Command
detailed_summary: The following day, as the princess is seated for dinner, she hears an unusual tapping and splashing sound approaching, followed by a knock at the door.
A small voice sings a verse, reminding the princess of their agreement made by the cool fountain in the woods.
The princess opens the door to find the frog, whom she had entirely forgotten.
Startled and frightened, she slams the door shut and returns to her seat.
Her father, the king, notices her distress and asks what frightened her.
She explains about the 'nasty frog' who retrieved her ball, the promise she made (believing he couldn't leave the spring), and his current presence at the door demanding entry.
As she speaks, the frog knocks again, repeating his poetic plea.
The king firmly instructs his daughter that she must keep her word and allow the frog inside.

events.text_segment:
The next day, just as the princess had sat down to dinner, she heard a strange noise—tap, tap—plash, plash—as if something was coming up the marble staircase: and soon afterwards there was a gentle knock at the door, and a little voice cried out and said:
‘Open the door, my princess dear,
  Open the door to thy true love here!
  And mind the words that thou and I said
  By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shade.’
Then the princess ran to the door and opened it, and there she saw the frog, whom she had quite forgotten. At this sight she was sadly frightened, and shutting the door as fast as she could came back to her seat. The king, her father, seeing that something had frightened her, asked her what was the matter. ‘There is a nasty frog,’ said she, ‘at the door, that lifted my ball for me out of the spring this morning: I told him that he should live with me here, thinking that he could never get out of the spring; but there he is at the door, and he wants to come in.’
While she was speaking the frog knocked again at the door, and said:
‘Open the door, my princess dear,
  Open the door to thy true love here!
  And mind the words that thou and I said
  By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shade.’
Then the king said to the young princess, ‘As you have given your word you must keep it; so go and let him in.’

events.title: Reluctant Hospitality: The First Night
detailed_summary: The princess obediently opens the door, and the frog hops into the room.
He makes his way across the floor with distinct tapping and splashing sounds until he reaches the princess's table.
The frog requests to be lifted onto her chair to sit beside her.
After she complies, he asks her to move her golden plate closer so he can share her meal.
Once the frog has eaten his fill, he declares he is tired and demands that the princess carry him upstairs to her bed.
The princess, with great reluctance, takes the frog in her hand and places him on the pillow of her own bed, where he remains for the entire night.
As soon as daylight breaks, the frog jumps from the bed, hops downstairs, and leaves the house.
The princess feels a sense of relief, believing her troubles with the frog are finally over.

As soon as it was light he jumped up, hopped downstairs, and went out of the house. ‘Now, then,’ thought the princess, ‘at last he is gone, and I shall be troubled with him no more.’

events.title: Joyful Union and Departure to a Happy Future
detailed_summary: The young princess quickly and happily agrees to the prince's proposal.
While they are conversing, a splendid coach arrives, drawn by eight beautiful horses adorned with feather plumes and golden harnesses.
Behind the coach rides the prince's devoted servant, Heinrich, whose heart had nearly broken from sorrow during his master's long enchantment.
The prince and princess bid farewell to the king.
They then board the coach with the eight horses and set off with great joy and celebration towards the prince's kingdom.
They reach their destination safely and live there in happiness for many years.

events.title: An Unlikely Alliance and a Winter Provision Plan
detailed_summary: A cat persuaded a mouse of her profound affection and friendship, which led to the mouse consenting to share a home with her.
The cat highlighted the importance of storing food for the upcoming winter to prevent starvation.
She also warned the mouse about the perils of venturing out independently, specifically mentioning the risk of traps.
Heeding this counsel, they jointly procured a pot of fat.
After careful consideration, the cat suggested hiding the pot of fat within the church, underneath the altar, believing this location would ensure its safety from theft.
They mutually agreed not to access the fat unless they faced a situation of genuine, dire need.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We will set it beneath the altar, and not touch it until we are really in need of it.’

events.text_segment: A certain cat had made the acquaintance of a mouse, and had said so much to her about the great love and friendship she felt for her, that at length the mouse agreed that they should live and keep house together. ‘But we must make a provision for winter, or else we shall suffer from hunger,’ said the cat; ‘and you, little mouse, cannot venture everywhere, or you will be caught in a trap some day.’ The good advice was followed, and a pot of fat was bought, but they did not know where to put it. At length, after much consideration, the cat said: ‘I know no place where it will be better stored up than in the church, for no one dares take anything away from there. We will set it beneath the altar, and not touch it until we are really in need of it.’

events.title: The Cat's First Deception: "Top-Off" Christened
detailed_summary: The pot of fat was securely placed in the church, but the cat soon felt an intense desire for it.
The cat fabricated a story about her cousin having a new son and requiring her to act as godmother at the christening, describing the imaginary infant as white with brown spots.
She asked for permission to leave for the day, entrusting the mouse with household duties.
The mouse willingly agreed, expressing a hopeful wish that the cat would think of her if any delicious food was available, particularly mentioning a longing for sweet red christening wine.
The cat's entire account was untrue; she neither had a cousin nor had she received an invitation to be a godmother.
She proceeded directly to the church, stealthily approached the pot of fat, and licked off the entire top layer.
Subsequently, she strolled along the town's rooftops, basked in the sun, and savored the thought of the pot of fat, only returning to their shared home in the evening.
The mouse welcomed her back, naturally assuming she had enjoyed a delightful day.
When questioned about the baby's name, the cat nonchalantly stated, "Top off!"
The mouse considered the name quite strange and out of the ordinary, inquiring if such a name was customary in the cat's family.
The cat brushed off the mouse's apprehension, retorting that the name was no more peculiar than "Crumb-stealer," a name she attributed to the mouse's own godchildren.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘What does that matter,’ said the cat, ‘it is no worse than Crumb-stealer, as your godchildren are called.’

Let me go out today, and you look after the house by yourself.’ ‘Yes, yes,’ answered the mouse, ‘by all means go, and if you get anything very good to eat, think of me. I should like a drop of sweet red christening wine myself.’ All this, however, was untrue; the cat had no cousin, and had not been asked to be godmother. She went straight to the church, stole to the pot of fat, began to lick at it, and licked the top of the fat off. events.title: The Cat's Second Deception: "Half-Done" Christened
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, the cat experienced another compelling urge for the stored fat.

She once more requested the mouse to look after the house alone for the day, inventing a second godmother invitation for a child she claimed had a distinctive white ring around its neck, an invitation she asserted she could not decline.
The kind-hearted mouse assented to the cat's request.
The cat, however, secretly went behind the town walls to the church and proceeded to eat half of the fat remaining in the pot.
She privately reflected that items kept hidden for oneself often provide the greatest pleasure and felt thoroughly content with her day's clandestine activities.
Upon her return home, the mouse inquired about the name given to this second child.
The cat announced that the child had been christened "Half-done."
The mouse was taken aback by this name, exclaiming that she had never encountered such a name in her entire life and would wager that it was not listed in any calendar.

events.title: The Cat's Third Deception: "All-Gone" Christened
detailed_summary: The cat's desire for more of the fat soon resurfaced, making her mouth water.
She rationalized her next departure by stating, "All good things go in threes," and concocted a third invitation to be a godmother.
She described this supposed infant as completely black with the sole exception of white paws, asserting that such a birth was a very infrequent event.
The mouse, already finding the names "Top-off" and "Half-done" peculiar and disquieting, voiced her growing unease.
The cat dismissed the mouse's worries, attributing her fanciful thoughts to her confinement indoors, clad in her "dark-grey fur coat and long tail," and her lack of outdoor experiences.
During the cat's absence, the mouse diligently cleaned their house and set everything in order.
Meanwhile, the insatiable cat consumed every last bit of the fat from the pot.
She mused to herself that a sense of tranquility comes when everything is eaten up, and returned home late in the evening, feeling satisfied and engorged.
The mouse immediately inquired about the name given to the third child.
The cat responded that this new name, "All-gone," was unlikely to please the mouse any more than the previous ones.

The mouse reacted with significant alarm, deeming "All-gone" the most suspicious name of all, one she had never encountered in written form, and pondered its potential meaning before unsettlingly curling up to sleep.

events.title: The Truth Revealed and the Mouse's Demise
detailed_summary: Following these events, the cat received no more (fabricated) invitations to be a godmother.
When winter arrived and external food sources disappeared, the mouse recalled their carefully stored provision.
She cheerfully proposed to the cat that they retrieve their pot of fat and enjoy its contents.
The cat replied with a biting sarcasm, suggesting the mouse would derive as much pleasure from it as she would from sticking her tongue out the window, implying there would be nothing to enjoy.
They journeyed to the church, and although the pot of fat was still in its designated spot, it was completely empty.
The mouse, aghast, exclaimed that she now understood the situation and that the cat's duplicity had come to light.
She accused the cat of having consumed all the fat during her supposed godmother excursions, beginning to recount the deceptive names: "First top off, then half-done, then—".
The cat furiously cut her off, threatening to devour the mouse as well if she uttered another word.
The name "All-gone" was already on the unfortunate mouse's lips; the moment she spoke it, the cat leaped upon her, captured her, and consumed her.
The narrator concludes with the somber reflection that this, indeed, reflects the nature of the world.

events.title: The Princess's Royal Upbringing and Journey Preparations with a Fairy's Gift
detailed_summary: Following the king's demise, the queen devotedly raised their exceptionally beautiful daughter, aided by a benevolent fairy.
When the princess reached adulthood, she was betrothed to a prince from a distant land.

As the time for her marriage and departure neared, the queen meticulously assembled a vast collection of costly items suitable for a royal bride, including jewels, precious metals, trinkets, and fine garments.
The queen also appointed a waiting-maid to accompany the princess on her journey and formally present her to the bridegroom.
Each was provided with a horse for travel; the princess's horse, named Falada, was a unique gift from the fairy and possessed the magical ability to speak.

Prior to the princess setting out, the good fairy visited her bed-chamber, carefully cut a lock of her own hair, and presented it to the princess, explaining it was a charm that could offer assistance during the journey.
After a poignant farewell ceremony involving all present, the princess placed the lock of hair in her bosom, mounted Falada, and embarked on her voyage to her bridegroom’s kingdom.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The king of a great land died, and left his queen to take care of their only child.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they all took a sorrowful leave of the princess; and she put the lock of hair into her bosom, got upon her horse, and set off on her journey to her bridegroom’s kingdom.

events.text_segment:
The king of a great land died, and left his queen to take care of their only child. This child was a daughter, who was very beautiful; and her mother loved her dearly, and was very kind to her. And there was a good fairy too, who was fond of the princess, and helped her mother to watch over her. When she grew up, she was betrothed to a prince who lived a great way off; and as the time drew near for her to be married, she got ready to set off on her journey to his country. Then the queen her mother, packed up a great many costly things; jewels, and gold, and silver; trinkets, fine dresses, and in short everything that became a royal bride. And she gave her a waiting-maid to ride with her, and give her into the bridegroom’s hands; and each had a horse for the journey. Now the princess’s horse was the fairy’s gift, and it was called Falada, and could speak.
When the time came for them to set out, the fairy went into her bed-chamber, and took a little knife, and cut off a lock of her hair, and gave it to the princess, and said, ‘Take care of it, dear child; for it is a charm that may be of use to you on the road.’ Then they all took a sorrowful leave of the princess; and she put the lock of hair into her bosom, got upon her horse, and set off on her journey to her bridegroom’s kingdom.
