events.text_segment: After that the peasants went home, and as they were entering the village, the small peasant also came quietly in, driving a flock of sheep and looking quite contented. Then the peasants were astonished, and said: ‘Peasant, from whence do you come? Have you come out of the water?’ ‘Yes, truly,’ replied the peasant, ‘I sank deep, deep down, until at last I got to the bottom; I pushed the bottom out of the barrel, and crept out, and there were pretty meadows on which a number of lambs were feeding, and from thence I brought this flock away with me.’ Said the peasants: ‘Are there any more there?’ ‘Oh, yes,’ said he, ‘more than I could want.’ Then the peasants made up their minds that they too would fetch some sheep for themselves, a flock apiece, but the mayor said: ‘I come first.’ So they went to the water together, and just then there were some of the small fleecy clouds in the blue sky, which are called little lambs, and they were reflected in the water, whereupon the peasants cried: ‘We already see the sheep down below!’ The mayor pressed forward and said: ‘I will go down first, and look about me, and if things promise well I’ll call you.’ So he jumped in; splash! went the water; it sounded as if he were calling them, and the whole crowd plunged in after him as one man. Then the entire village was dead, and the small peasant, as sole heir, became a rich man.

events.title: Catherine's Culinary Catastrophes and Cleanup
detailed_summary: Frederick requested his wife, Catherine, to prepare a good meal and ale for his return from working in the fields.
Catherine started frying their only steak and then went to the cellar to fetch ale.
While tapping the ale, she worried that the unsecured dog might steal the cooking steak.
Her fear materialized; she rushed upstairs to find the dog escaping with the steak in its mouth.
Catherine pursued the dog across a field but failed to retrieve the meat, eventually giving up and returning home tired.
Upon her return, she discovered that the ale tap had been left open, causing the entire cask to empty onto the cellar floor.
To manage the spillage, Catherine decided to use a sack of fine meal to absorb the ale.
In her attempt to apply the solution, she accidentally knocked over the jug of ale she had initially collected, adding to the mess.
She then spread the meal all over the cellar floor, feeling pleased with how clean and neat it looked despite the series of mishaps.
When Frederick arrived and asked for his dinner, Catherine recounted the loss of the steak to the dog, the spillage of all the ale, and how the meal was used to clean up the cellar.
Frederick questioned her choices, and Catherine defended herself by stating she was unaware she was doing anything wrong as he had not previously instructed her otherwise.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Why, Frederick,’ said she, ‘I did not know I was doing wrong; you should have told me before.’

events.text_segment:
There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married. One day Frederick said. ‘Kate! I am going to work in the fields; when I come back I shall be hungry so let me have something nice cooked, and a good draught of ale.’ ‘Very well,’ said she, ‘it shall all be ready.’ When dinner-time drew nigh, Catherine took a nice steak, which was all the meat she had, and put it on the fire to fry. The steak soon began to look brown, and to crackle in the pan; and Catherine stood by with a fork and turned it: then she said to herself, ‘The steak is almost ready, I may as well go to the cellar for the ale.’ So she left the pan on the fire and took a large jug and went into the cellar and tapped the ale cask. The beer ran into the jug and Catherine stood looking on. At last it popped into her head, ‘The dog is not shut up—he may be running away with the steak; that’s well thought of.’ So up she ran from the cellar; and sure enough the rascally cur had got the steak in his mouth, and was making off with it.
Away ran Catherine, and away ran the dog across the field: but he ran faster than she, and stuck close to the steak. ‘It’s all gone, and “what can’t be cured must be endured”,’ said Catherine. So she turned round; and as she had run a good way and was tired, she walked home leisurely to cool herself.
Now all this time the ale was running too, for Catherine had not turned the cock; and when the jug was full the liquor ran upon the floor till the cask was empty. When she got to the cellar stairs she saw what had happened. ‘My stars!’ said she, ‘what shall I do to keep Frederick from seeing all this slopping about?’ So she thought a while; and at last remembered that there was a sack of fine meal bought at the last fair, and that if she sprinkled this over the floor it would suck up the ale nicely. ‘What a lucky thing,’ said she, ‘that we kept that meal! we have now a good use for it.’ So away she went for it: but she managed to set it down just upon the great jug full of beer, and upset it; and thus all the ale that had been saved was set swimming on the floor also. ‘Ah! well,’ said she, ‘when one goes another may as well follow.’ Then she strewed the meal all about the cellar, and was quite pleased with her cleverness, and said, ‘How very neat and clean it looks!’
At noon Frederick came home. ‘Now, wife,’ cried he, ‘what have you for dinner?’ ‘O Frederick!’ answered she, ‘I was cooking you a steak; but while I went down to draw the ale, the dog ran away with it; and while I ran after him, the ale ran out; and when I went to dry up the ale with the sack of meal that we got at the fair, I upset the jug: but the cellar is now quite dry, and looks so clean!’ ‘Kate, Kate,’ said he, ‘how could you do all this?’ Why did you leave the steak to fry, and the ale to run, and then spoil all the meal?’ ‘Why, Frederick,’ said she, ‘I did not know I was doing wrong; you should have told me before.’

One day Frederick said, 'Catherine, I am going out to work in the fields; have a good dinner ready for me when I come back. A fine roasted meat, and mind you, a cool draught of ale to go with it.'

'Go your way, Frederick,' said Catherine, 'I will see to it all.'

As soon as Frederick was gone, Catherine set to work. She put a fine piece of meat on to roast over the fire. While it was sputtering and browning nicely, she thought to herself, 'The meat will be some time; I may as well go down to the cellar and draw the ale.' So she took a jug, went down into the cellar, and turned the tap on the great barrel of ale. She placed the jug underneath but then, looking up, she spied a beetle crawling on the ceiling directly above her. A sudden and dreadful thought struck her. 'Oh, you poor, unfortunate thing!' she cried, thinking not of the beetle but of herself. 'What if I were to have a child, and that child were to come down here to draw ale, and that very beetle were to fall into its mouth and choke it to death!'

At this terrible thought, she dropped the jug, sat down on the cellar steps, and began to weep and wail most piteously for the grandchild she did not have. All the while, the ale from the barrel ran out of the tap, across the floor, and made a great golden puddle that grew larger and larger until the whole cellar was swimming in it.

Upstairs, the roast sizzled and cooked. The dog, smelling the delicious aroma and hearing no one about, crept into the kitchen, snatched the meat from the spit, and ran out of the door with it. 

After a long while, Catherine heard the gurgling sound from the barrel as it emptied. She jumped up, realizing her folly. 'Oh dear!' she exclaimed, 'The ale is lost!' events.title: The Barter of Gold 'Buttons' for Earthenware
detailed_summary: Concerned by Catherine's financial decisions, Frederick decided to test her by hiding his gold.
He told Catherine his gold coins were merely 'pretty yellow buttons,' which he would bury in the garden, and strictly forbade her from touching them or going near the spot.
Catherine promised not to interfere with the buried 'buttons.'
Soon after Frederick left, pedlars came by selling earthenware plates and dishes.
Catherine expressed a wish to purchase their goods but lamented her lack of money.
She then proposed a trade, offering the 'yellow buttons' she knew were buried in the garden.
When the pedlars showed interest, Catherine directed them to the burial spot, explaining she herself was not allowed to dig them up.
The pedlars unearthed the gold, took all of it, and in exchange, left Catherine with a large assortment of earthenware.
Pleased with her transaction, Catherine arranged the new plates and dishes for display throughout the house.
Frederick returned to find his home filled with earthenware and was aghast to learn that Catherine had traded all his 'yellow buttons'—his entire fortune—for them.
Catherine, once again, claimed ignorance of any wrongdoing, asserting that he should have been more specific in his instructions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The husband thought to himself, ‘If my wife manages matters thus, I must look sharp myself.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Why,’ answered she, ‘I did not know there was any harm in it; you should have told me.’

events.text_segment: The husband thought to himself, ‘If my wife manages matters thus, I must look sharp myself.’ Now he had a good deal of gold in the house: so he said to Catherine, ‘What pretty yellow buttons these are! I shall put them into a box and bury them in the garden; but take care that you never go near or meddle with them.’ ‘No, Frederick,’ said she, ‘that I never will.’ As soon as he was gone, there came by some pedlars with earthenware plates and dishes, and they asked her whether she would buy. ‘Oh dear me, I should like to buy very much, but I have no money: if you had any use for yellow buttons, I might deal with you.’ ‘Yellow buttons!’ said they: ‘let us have a look at them.’ ‘Go into the garden and dig where I tell you, and you will find the yellow buttons: I dare not go myself.’ So the rogues went: and when they found what these yellow buttons were, they took them all away, and left her plenty of plates and dishes. Then she set them all about the house for a show: and when Frederick came back, he cried out, ‘Kate, what have you been doing?’ ‘See,’ said she, ‘I have bought all these with your yellow buttons: but I did not touch them myself; the pedlars went themselves and dug them up.’ ‘Wife, wife,’ said Frederick, ‘what a pretty piece of work you have made! those yellow buttons were all my money: how came you to do such a thing?’ ‘Why,’ answered she, ‘I did not know there was any harm in it; you should have told me.’

events.title: The Pursuit and Misadventures with Provisions
detailed_summary: Catherine suggested to Frederick that they should pursue the thieves (the pedlars) to reclaim their stolen gold.
Frederick agreed and instructed her to pack some butter and cheese for their journey.
As they set out, Frederick walked faster, leaving Catherine some distance behind.
Catherine noticed trees along the path that were chafed and damaged by cart wheels.
Feeling compassionate, she decided to use all the butter she had brought to grease the tree trunks, hoping to protect them from further injury.
While she was tending to the trees, one of the cheeses fell from her basket and rolled down a nearby hill, disappearing from sight.
Believing the second cheese could find the first, as it had 'younger legs,' Catherine intentionally rolled it down the hill in the same direction.
She assumed both cheeses would know the way and eventually follow her, so she continued her journey without waiting.
Upon catching up with Frederick, he asked for the food they had packed.
Catherine presented him with only dry bread, explaining she had used the butter to grease the trees and had sent both cheeses rolling down the hill to find each other.
Frederick called her a 'goose' for her silly actions, to which Catherine replied that he had never told her not to do such things.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Catherine stood musing for a while, and at last said to her husband, ‘Hark ye, Frederick, we will soon get the gold back: let us run after the thieves.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘How can you say so?’ said she; ‘I am sure you never told me not.’

events.text_segment:
Catherine stood musing for a while, and at last said to her husband, ‘Hark ye, Frederick, we will soon get the gold back: let us run after the thieves.’ ‘Well, we will try,’ answered he; ‘but take some butter and cheese with you, that we may have something to eat by the way.’ ‘Very well,’ said she; and they set out: and as Frederick walked the fastest, he left his wife some way behind. ‘It does not matter,’ thought she: ‘when we turn back, I shall be so much nearer home than he.’
Presently she came to the top of a hill, down the side of which there was a road so narrow that the cart wheels always chafed the trees on each side as they passed. ‘Ah, see now,’ said she, ‘how they have bruised and wounded those poor trees; they will never get well.’ So she took pity on them, and made use of the butter to grease them all, so that the wheels might not hurt them so much. While she was doing this kind office one of her cheeses fell out of the basket, and rolled down the hill. Catherine looked, but could not see where it had gone; so she said, ‘Well, I suppose the other will go the same way and find you; he has younger legs than I have.’ Then she rolled the other cheese after it; and away it went, nobody knows where, down the hill. But she said she supposed that they knew the road, and would follow her, and she could not stay there all day waiting for them.
At last she overtook Frederick, who desired her to give him something to eat. Then she gave him the dry bread. ‘Where are the butter and cheese?’ said he. ‘Oh!’ answered she, ‘I used the butter to grease those poor trees that the wheels chafed so: and one of the cheeses ran away so I sent the other after it to find it, and I suppose they are both on the road together somewhere.’ ‘What a goose you are to do such silly things!’ said the husband. ‘How can you say so?’ said she; ‘I am sure you never told me not.’

events.title: Securing the House by Carrying Its Door
detailed_summary: After their meager meal of dry bread, Frederick asked Catherine if she had locked the house door securely before they left.
Catherine admitted she had not, reasoning that he hadn't explicitly told her to do so.
Frederick then sent her back home to lock the door and to bring along something more to eat.
On her way, Catherine decided that Frederick might not want more butter and cheese and opted instead to bring a bag of fine nuts and a bottle of vinegar, items she had observed him consuming before.
Upon reaching their house, she bolted the back door as instructed.
However, for the front door, she reasoned that the safest course of action, in line with Frederick's desire to 'lock the door,' was to take it with her entirely.
She therefore removed the front door from its hinges and carried it along as she returned to Frederick.
When she met Frederick, she proudly presented the door, suggesting he could now keep it under his personal watch.
Frederick was utterly dismayed by this interpretation, exclaiming about her 'cleverness' and how removing the door left the house completely vulnerable.
He then declared that as a consequence of her actions, she would have to carry the door herself.

Catherine agreed to carry the door but stated that the combined weight of the door, nuts, and vinegar would be too much. She proposed fastening the nuts and vinegar to the door, a suggestion to which Frederick raised no objection.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They ate the dry bread together; and Frederick said, ‘Kate, I hope you locked the door safe when you came away.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Very well,’ answered she, ‘I’ll carry the door; but I’ll not carry the nuts and vinegar bottle also—that would be too much of a load; so if you please, I’ll fasten them to the door.’

events.text_segment:
They ate the dry bread together; and Frederick said, ‘Kate, I hope you locked the door safe when you came away.’ ‘No,’ answered she, ‘you did not tell me.’ ‘Then go home, and do it now before we go any farther,’ said Frederick, ‘and bring with you something to eat.’
Catherine did as he told her, and thought to herself by the way, ‘Frederick wants something to eat; but I don’t think he is very fond of butter and cheese: I’ll bring him a bag of fine nuts, and the vinegar, for I have often seen him take some.’
When she reached home, she bolted the back door, but the front door she took off the hinges, and said, ‘Frederick told me to lock the door, but surely it can nowhere be so safe if I take it with me.’ So she took her time by the way; and when she overtook her husband she cried out, ‘There, Frederick, there is the door itself, you may watch it as carefully as you please.’ ‘Alas! alas!’ said he, ‘what a clever wife I have! I sent you to make the house fast, and you take the door away, so that everybody may go in and out as they please—however, as you have brought the door, you shall carry it about with you for your pains.’ ‘Very well,’ answered she, ‘I’ll carry the door; but I’ll not carry the nuts and vinegar bottle also—that would be too much of a load; so if you please, I’ll fasten them to the door.’

events.title: Accidental Recapture of Gold Through a Series of Mishaps
detailed_summary: Frederick and Catherine continued into the woods to search for the thieves but couldn't find them. As night fell, they climbed a tree to rest.
The very thieves they were seeking coincidentally set up camp and made a fire directly beneath the tree where Frederick and Catherine were hidden.
Frederick attempted to drive the thieves away by dropping stones on their heads from above.
The thieves, unaware of Frederick and Catherine's presence, merely commented that it must be morning and the wind was shaking fir-apples from the trees.
Catherine, who was carrying the heavy door on her shoulder with the nuts and vinegar attached, grew very tired. She mistakenly believed the nuts were the main source of the weight.
She informed Frederick she had to drop the nuts. Despite his warning that it would reveal their presence, she insisted and let them fall.
The nuts rattled down, leading one of the thieves to remark that it was hailing.
A short time later, still feeling the door's oppressive weight, Catherine whispered to Frederick that she must now throw down the vinegar.
Frederick again pleaded with her not to, fearing discovery, but Catherine was resolute and poured the vinegar down.
The thieves below simply commented on the unexpectedly heavy dew.
Finally, Catherine realized it was the door itself that was so heavy. She told Frederick she had to drop it.
He begged her not to, certain it would expose them, but Catherine let the door go. It crashed down onto the thieves with a tremendous clatter.
Terrified by the noise and the falling door, the thieves cried 'Murder!' and fled as fast as they could, abandoning all the stolen gold.
Frederick and Catherine then climbed down from the tree and found all their money recovered.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Frederick of course made no objection to that plan, and they set off into the wood to look for the thieves; but they could not find them: and when it grew dark, they climbed up into a tree to spend the night there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So when Frederick and Catherine came down, there they found all their money safe and sound.

events.text_segment:
Frederick of course made no objection to that plan, and they set off into the wood to look for the thieves; but they could not find them: and when it grew dark, they climbed up into a tree to spend the night there. Scarcely were they up, than who should come by but the very rogues they were looking for. They were in truth great rascals, and belonged to that class of people who find things before they are lost; they were tired; so they sat down and made a fire under the very tree where Frederick and Catherine were. Frederick slipped down on the other side, and picked up some stones. Then he climbed up again, and tried to hit the thieves on the head with them: but they only said, ‘It must be near morning, for the wind shakes the fir-apples down.’
Catherine, who had the door on her shoulder, began to be very tired; but she thought it was the nuts upon it that were so heavy: so she said softly, ‘Frederick, I must let the nuts go.’ ‘No,’ answered he, ‘not now, they will discover us.’ ‘I can’t help that: they must go.’ ‘Well, then, make haste and throw them down, if you will.’ Then away rattled the nuts down among the boughs and one of the thieves cried, ‘Bless me, it is hailing.’
A little while after, Catherine thought the door was still very heavy: so she whispered to Frederick, ‘I must throw the vinegar down.’ ‘Pray don’t,’ answered he, ‘it will discover us.’ ‘I can’t help that,’ said she, ‘go it must.’ So she poured all the vinegar down; and the thieves said, ‘What a heavy dew there is!’
At last it popped into Catherine’s head that it was the door itself that was so heavy all the time: so she whispered, ‘Frederick, I must throw the door down soon.’ But he begged and prayed her not to do so, for he was sure it would betray them. ‘Here goes, however,’ said she: and down went the door with such a clatter upon the thieves, that they cried out ‘Murder!’ and not knowing what was coming, ran away as fast as they could, and left all the gold. So when Frederick and Catherine came down, there they found all their money safe and sound.

events.title: The Witch's Murderous Plot and the Stepdaughter's Clever Evasion
detailed_summary: A witch favored her own malevolent and unattractive daughter while despising her kind and beautiful stepdaughter.
The witch's daughter coveted the stepdaughter's pretty apron, prompting the witch to promise her the item.
The witch planned to decapitate her stepdaughter that night while she slept, instructing her own daughter to ensure she was safely positioned away from the front of the bed.
The stepdaughter, having overheard the entire murderous plan, was forced to stay indoors all day.
At bedtime, the witch's daughter took the safer position in bed first.
Once the witch's daughter was asleep, the stepdaughter quietly moved her to the front of the bed and took the protected spot near the wall for herself.
During the night, the witch entered, felt for the person at the front of the bed, and, mistaking her for the stepdaughter, killed her own child with an axe.

events.text_segment: There was once upon a time a woman who was a real witch and had two daughters, one ugly and wicked, and this one she loved because she was her own daughter, and one beautiful and good, and this one she hated, because she was her stepdaughter. The stepdaughter once had a pretty apron, which the other fancied so much that she became envious, and told her mother that she must and would have that apron. ‘Be quiet, my child,’ said the old woman, ‘and you shall have it. Your stepsister has long deserved death; tonight when she is asleep I will come and cut her head off. Only be careful that you are at the far side of the bed, and push her well to the front.’ It would have been all over with the poor girl if she had not just then been standing in a corner, and heard everything. All day long she dared not go out of doors, and when bedtime had come, the witch’s daughter got into bed first, so as to lie at the far side, but when she was asleep, the other pushed her gently to the front, and took for herself the place at the back, close by the wall. In the night, the old woman came creeping in, she held an axe in her right hand, and felt with her left to see if anyone were lying at the outside, and then she grasped the axe with both hands, and cut her own child’s head off.

events.title: The Escape Plan with Roland and the Deceptive Blood Drops
detailed_summary: After the witch left, the stepdaughter went to her sweetheart, Roland, and urged him to flee with her immediately.
She explained that her stepmother had intended to kill her but had mistakenly killed her own child instead, and they would be in grave danger once the witch discovered the truth at daybreak.
Roland advised her to first secure the witch's magic wand, as it would be crucial for their escape if pursued.
The maiden retrieved the magic wand.
She then took the severed head of the witch's daughter and strategically placed three drops of blood: one before the bed, one in the kitchen, and one on the stairs, to mislead the witch.
Following these preparations, she and Roland quickly departed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When she had gone away, the girl got up and went to her sweetheart, who was called Roland, and knocked at his door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she hurried away with her lover.

events.text_segment: When she had gone away, the girl got up and went to her sweetheart, who was called Roland, and knocked at his door. When he came out, she said to him: ‘Listen, dearest Roland, we must fly in all haste; my stepmother wanted to kill me, but has struck her own child. When daylight comes, and she sees what she has done, we shall be lost.’ ‘But,’ said Roland, ‘I counsel you first to take away her magic wand, or we cannot escape if she pursues us.’ The maiden fetched the magic wand, and she took the dead girl’s head and dropped three drops of blood on the ground, one in front of the bed, one in the kitchen, and one on the stairs. Then she hurried away with her lover.

events.title: The Witch's Gruesome Discovery and Furious Pursuit
detailed_summary: The next morning, the old witch called for her daughter, intending to give her the apron, but received no reply.
When the witch called out, "Where are you?", the first drop of blood, positioned on the stairs, answered that it was sweeping.
The witch went to the stairs but found no one and called out again.
The second drop of blood, in the kitchen, responded that it was warming itself.
She went to the kitchen, again finding no one, and called out a third time.
The third drop of blood, by the bed, replied that it was sleeping.
The witch then went to the bedroom and discovered her own child, decapitated and covered in blood.
Enraged, she looked out the window and, with her ability to see far into the world, spotted her stepdaughter and Roland fleeing.
Declaring they would not escape, she donned her magical many-league boots, which allowed her to cover an hour's distance with each step, and quickly began to catch up to them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the old witch got up next morning, she called her daughter, and wanted to give her the apron, but she did not come.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She put on her many-league boots, in which she covered an hour’s walk at every step, and it was not long before she overtook them.

events.text_segment: When the old witch got up next morning, she called her daughter, and wanted to give her the apron, but she did not come. Then the witch cried: ‘Where are you?’ ‘Here, on the stairs, I am sweeping,’ answered the first drop of blood. The old woman went out, but saw no one on the stairs, and cried again: ‘Where are you?’ ‘Here in the kitchen, I am warming myself,’ cried the second drop of blood. She went into the kitchen, but found no one. Then she cried again: ‘Where are you?’ ‘Ah, here in the bed, I am sleeping,’ cried the third drop of blood. She went into the room to the bed. What did she see there? Her own child, whose head she had cut off, bathed in her blood. The witch fell into a passion, sprang to the window, and as she could look forth quite far into the world, she perceived her stepdaughter hurrying away with her sweetheart Roland. ‘That shall not help you,’ cried she, ‘even if you have got a long way off, you shall still not escape me.’ She put on her many-league boots, in which she covered an hour’s walk at every step, and it was not long before she overtook them.

events.title: Magical Transformations Thwart the Witch's Pursuit
detailed_summary: Seeing the witch approaching, the maiden used the magic wand to transform Roland into a lake and herself into a duck swimming on it.
The witch attempted to lure the duck by throwing breadcrumbs from the shore but was unsuccessful and had to return home empty-handed as night fell.
The maiden and Roland then reverted to their human forms and continued their journey throughout the night until morning.
As dawn broke, the maiden changed herself into a beautiful flower in a briar hedge and Roland into a fiddler.
When the witch arrived and asked the fiddler if she could pick the flower, he agreed and offered to play music for her.
As the witch, knowing the flower's true identity, entered the hedge to pick it, the fiddler began to play a magical tune.
The music compelled the witch to dance uncontrollably; the faster he played, the more furiously she danced.
The thorns tore her clothes and skin, causing her to bleed, and as the fiddler continued playing, she danced until she died.

events.text_segment: The girl, however, when she saw the old woman striding towards her, changed, with her magic wand, her sweetheart Roland into a lake, and herself into a duck swimming in the middle of it. The witch placed herself on the shore, threw breadcrumbs in, and went to endless trouble to entice the duck; but the duck did not let herself be enticed, and the old woman had to go home at night as she had come. At this the girl and her sweetheart Roland resumed their natural shapes again, and they walked on the whole night until daybreak. Then the maiden changed herself into a beautiful flower which stood in the midst of a briar hedge, and her sweetheart Roland into a fiddler. It was not long before the witch came striding up towards them, and said to the musician: ‘Dear musician, may I pluck that beautiful flower for myself?’ ‘Oh, yes,’ he replied, ‘I will play to you while you do it.’ As she was hastily creeping into the hedge and was just going to pluck the flower, knowing perfectly well who the flower was, he began to play, and whether she would or not, she was forced to dance, for it was a magical dance. The faster he played, the more violent springs was she forced to make, and the thorns tore her clothes from her body, and pricked her and wounded her till she bled, and as he did not stop, she had to dance till she lay dead on the ground.

events.title: Roland's Departure and the Maiden's Transformation into a Landmark
detailed_summary: Now free from the witch, Roland announced his intention to go to his father and make arrangements for their wedding.
The maiden said she would wait for him there.
To remain unrecognized while she waited, she transformed herself into a red stone landmark.
Roland then departed, leaving the maiden as a stone in the field awaiting his return.

events.title: Roland's Betrayal and the Maiden's Despairing Transformation
detailed_summary: Upon reaching home, Roland was ensnared by another woman who captivated him, causing him to completely forget the maiden.
The maiden, in her form as a landmark, waited for a considerable time.
When Roland did not return, she grew deeply saddened and, in her despair, changed herself into a flower.
She hoped that someone passing by would inadvertently step on her and end her suffering.

events.title: The Shepherd's Discovery and the Wise Woman's Counsel
detailed_summary: A shepherd tending his flock in the field noticed the beautiful flower.
He picked it, took it home, and stored it in his chest.
Subsequently, peculiar events began occurring in the shepherd's house.
Each morning when he woke, all his chores were mysteriously completed: the room was swept, furniture cleaned, the fire lit, and water fetched.
At midday, he would return home to find a table set with a good dinner.
The shepherd was baffled by these occurrences, as he never saw anyone in his house and couldn't imagine how someone could hide there.
Though pleased with the assistance, he eventually became frightened and sought advice from a wise woman.

The wise woman informed him that enchantment was at play and instructed him to listen carefully early one morning for any movement in his room. If he saw anything, regardless of its form, he was to throw a white cloth over it to stop the magic.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It befell, however, that a shepherd kept his sheep in the field and saw the flower, and as it was so pretty, plucked it, took it with him, and laid it away in his chest.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The wise woman said: ‘There is some enchantment behind it, listen very early some morning if anything is moving in the room, and if you see anything, no matter what it is, throw a white cloth over it, and then the magic will be stopped.’

events.text_segment: It befell, however, that a shepherd kept his sheep in the field and saw the flower, and as it was so pretty, plucked it, took it with him, and laid it away in his chest. From that time forth, strange things happened in the shepherd’s house. When he arose in the morning, all the work was already done, the room was swept, the table and benches cleaned, the fire in the hearth was lighted, and the water was fetched, and at noon, when he came home, the table was laid, and a good dinner served. He could not conceive how this came to pass, for he never saw a human being in his house, and no one could have concealed himself in it. He was certainly pleased with this good attendance, but still at last he was so afraid that he went to a wise woman and asked for her advice. The wise woman said: ‘There is some enchantment behind it, listen very early some morning if anything is moving in the room, and if you see anything, no matter what it is, throw a white cloth over it, and then the magic will be stopped.’

events.title: The Maiden Revealed and Her Steadfast Loyalty
detailed_summary: The shepherd followed the wise woman's instructions.
The next morning at dawn, he observed his chest opening and the flower emerging from it.
He quickly sprang forward and cast a white cloth over the flower.
The transformation instantly ceased, and a beautiful girl stood before him.
She confessed that she had been the flower and had been secretly managing his household.
The maiden recounted her story to the shepherd.
Pleased with her, he asked for her hand in marriage.
She declined, stating her desire to remain faithful to her sweetheart Roland, even though he had abandoned her.
However, she promised to stay and continue her housekeeping duties for the shepherd.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Nevertheless, she promised not to go away, but to continue keeping house for the shepherd.

events.text_segment: The shepherd did as she bade him, and next morning just as day dawned, he saw the chest open, and the flower come out. Swiftly he sprang towards it, and threw a white cloth over it. Instantly the transformation came to an end, and a beautiful girl stood before him, who admitted to him that she had been the flower, and that up to this time she had attended to his house-keeping. She told him her story, and as she pleased him he asked her if she would marry him, but she answered: ‘No,’ for she wanted to remain faithful to her sweetheart Roland, although he had deserted her. Nevertheless, she promised not to go away, but to continue keeping house for the shepherd.

She answered, "No," because she wanted to keep faith with her sweetheart Roland, although he had deserted her; but she promised not to go away, but to continue to keep house for him.

Her hair was like spun gold, and her eyes were the color of the summer sky. She smiled at him gently.

events.title: The Wedding Song and Roland's Renewed Memory
detailed_summary: The time for Roland's wedding approached, and a local custom required all girls to attend and sing in honor of the couple.
The faithful maiden, upon hearing this, was overcome with sadness, feeling her heart might break, and did not want to go.
However, the other girls came and compelled her to attend.
When it was her turn to sing, she held back until she was the very last one remaining and could no longer refuse.
As she began her song, the sound reached Roland's ears.
He immediately jumped up, exclaiming that he recognized the voice as that of his true bride and that he would marry no other.
All his forgotten memories of her and their past together suddenly returned to his heart.

events.title: Snowdrop's Prophetic Birth and the Vain Queen's Introduction
detailed_summary: A queen, while sewing by an ebony window in winter, pricks her finger, and three drops of blood fall on the snow.
She expresses a wish for a daughter with skin as white as snow, lips as red as blood, and hair as black as ebony.
Her daughter, named Snowdrop, is subsequently born with these exact physical characteristics.
After some time, the original queen passes away.
The king takes a new wife, who is very beautiful but exceedingly vain and cannot tolerate the idea of anyone being more attractive than her.
This new queen possesses a magical looking-glass.
She regularly consults her mirror, inquiring who is the most beautiful woman in the realm.
The mirror consistently reassures her that she, the queen, holds the title of the fairest.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was the middle of winter, when the broad flakes of snow were falling around, that the queen of a country many thousand miles off sat working at her window.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence:
And the glass had always answered:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest in all the land.’

events.text_segment:
It was the middle of winter, when the broad flakes of snow were falling around, that the queen of a country many thousand miles off sat working at her window. The frame of the window was made of fine black ebony, and as she sat looking out upon the snow, she pricked her finger, and three drops of blood fell upon it. Then she gazed thoughtfully upon the red drops that sprinkled the white snow, and said, ‘Would that my little daughter may be as white as that snow, as red as that blood, and as black as this ebony windowframe!’ And so the little girl really did grow up; her skin was as white as snow, her cheeks as rosy as the blood, and her hair as black as ebony; and she was called Snowdrop.
But this queen died; and the king soon married another wife, who became queen, and was very beautiful, but so vain that she could not bear to think that anyone could be handsomer than she was. She had a fairy looking-glass, to which she used to go, and then she would gaze upon herself in it, and say:
‘Tell me, glass, tell me true!
  Of all the ladies in the land,
  Who is fairest, tell me, who?’
And the glass had always answered:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest in all the land.’

events.title: The Queen's Jealousy, Snowdrop's Banishment, and the Servant's Mercy
detailed_summary: Snowdrop's beauty flourishes as she grows, and by the age of seven, she is as radiant as daylight and more beautiful than the queen herself.
One day, when the queen consults her magic mirror as usual, it declares that while the queen is fair, Snowdrop is far lovelier.
Hearing this, the queen becomes pale with rage and envy.
She summons one of her servants and commands him to take Snowdrop into the vast woods, intending never to see her again.
The servant leads Snowdrop away; however, his heart softens when Snowdrop tearfully begs him to spare her life.
He tells the pretty child he will not harm her and leaves her by herself in the woods.

Although he believes it highly probable that wild beasts will devour her, he feels a significant burden lifted from his heart for choosing not to kill her, leaving her destiny to chance and the possibility of rescue.

events.text_segment:
But Snowdrop grew more and more beautiful; and when she was seven years old she was as bright as the day, and fairer than the queen herself. Then the glass one day answered the queen, when she went to look in it as usual:
‘Thou, queen, art fair, and beauteous to see,
  But Snowdrop is lovelier far than thee!’
When she heard this she turned pale with rage and envy, and called to one of her servants, and said, ‘Take Snowdrop away into the wide wood, that I may never see her any more.’ Then the servant led her away; but his heart melted when Snowdrop begged him to spare her life, and he said, ‘I will not hurt you, thou pretty child.’ So he left her by herself; and though he thought it most likely that the wild beasts would tear her in pieces, he felt as if a great weight were taken off his heart when he had made up his mind not to kill her but to leave her to her fate, with the chance of someone finding and saving her.

events.title: Snowdrop's Discovery of the Seven Dwarfs' Cottage
detailed_summary: Poor Snowdrop wanders through the woods in great terror, with wild beasts roaring around her, yet none cause her any harm.
In the evening, she arrives at a cottage situated among the hills and enters to rest, as her small feet can carry her no further.
Everything inside the cottage is well-kept and orderly.
A white cloth is spread on the table, set with seven small plates, seven little loaves, seven small glasses containing wine, and seven sets of knives and forks, all neatly arranged.
Against the wall, there are seven small beds.
Feeling very hungry, she takes a small piece from each loaf and sips a tiny amount of wine from each glass.
After eating and drinking, she decides to lie down and rest.
She tries all the little beds; one is too long, another too short, until finally, the seventh bed suits her perfectly, and there she lies down and falls asleep.

events.title: The Dwarfs' Welcome and Snowdrop's New Home
detailed_summary: After some time, the occupants of the cottage, who are seven small dwarfs that search for gold in the mountains, return home.
They light their seven lamps and immediately notice that something is amiss.

The first dwarf asks who sat on his stool, the second who ate from his plate, the third who took his bread, the fourth who touched his spoon, the fifth who handled his fork, the sixth who cut with his knife, and the seventh who drank his wine.
Then, the first dwarf looks around and asks who has been lying on his bed.
The other dwarfs rush to him, each exclaiming that someone has been on their bed.
However, the seventh dwarf spots Snowdrop and calls his brothers to see her.
They exclaim in wonder and astonishment at her loveliness, bringing their lamps closer for a better look.
Pleased to see her, they take care not to disturb her sleep, and the seventh dwarf sleeps for an hour with each of the other dwarfs in turn until morning.
In the morning, Snowdrop shares her entire story with the dwarfs.
They feel sorry for her and propose that if she manages their household tasks like cooking, washing, knitting, and spinning, she can stay with them, and they will ensure her well-being.
The dwarfs then depart for their daily work of seeking gold and silver in the mountains, leaving Snowdrop at home.
Before leaving, they caution her that the queen will soon discover her whereabouts and advise her to be careful and not allow anyone into the cottage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By and by in came the masters of the cottage.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they went out all day long to their work, seeking for gold and silver in the mountains: but Snowdrop was left at home; and they warned her, and said, ‘The queen will soon find out where you are, so take care and let no one in.’

events.text_segment:
By and by in came the masters of the cottage. Now they were seven little dwarfs, that lived among the mountains, and dug and searched for gold. They lighted up their seven lamps, and saw at once that all was not right. The first said, ‘Who has been sitting on my stool?’ The second, ‘Who has been eating off my plate?’ The third, ‘Who has been picking my bread?’ The fourth, ‘Who has been meddling with my spoon?’ The fifth, ‘Who has been handling my fork?’ The sixth, ‘Who has been cutting with my knife?’ The seventh, ‘Who has been drinking my wine?’ Then the first looked round and said, ‘Who has been lying on my bed?’ And the rest came running to him, and everyone cried out that somebody had been upon his bed. But the seventh saw Snowdrop, and called all his brethren to come and see her; and they cried out with wonder and astonishment and brought their lamps to look at her, and said, ‘Good heavens! what a lovely child she is!’ And they were very glad to see her, and took care not to wake her; and the seventh dwarf slept an hour with each of the other dwarfs in turn, till the night was gone.
In the morning Snowdrop told them all her story; and they pitied her, and said if she would keep all things in order, and cook and wash and knit and spin for them, she might stay where she was, and they would take good care of her. Then they went out all day long to their work, seeking for gold and silver in the mountains: but Snowdrop was left at home; and they warned her, and said, ‘The queen will soon find out where you are, so take care and let no one in.’

events.title: The Queen's First Murder Attempt: The Laced Bodice
detailed_summary: The queen, under the impression that Snowdrop is dead, believes herself to be the most beautiful woman in the land and consults her mirror.
The mirror, however, reveals that the queen is the fairest in her immediate vicinity, but Snowdrop is hiding with the seven dwarfs over the hills and is far lovelier.
The queen is deeply frightened, knowing the mirror always speaks truth, and realizes her servant must have betrayed her.
Unable to bear the thought of someone more beautiful being alive, she disguises herself as an old pedlar woman and travels to the dwarfs' dwelling.
She knocks on the door, crying out that she has fine wares for sale.
Snowdrop looks out the window and inquires about the goods.
The disguised queen offers laces and bobbins of all colors.
Snowdrop, thinking the old woman seems kind, decides to let her in.
The old woman comments on how poorly Snowdrop's stays are laced and offers to lace them properly with one of her new, nice laces.
Snowdrop, suspecting no ill intent, stands before the old woman, who quickly and tightly pulls the lace, causing Snowdrop to lose her breath and fall as if dead.
The spiteful queen, believing Snowdrop's beauty finished, departs for home.
In the evening, the seven dwarfs return and are greatly grieved to find Snowdrop motionless on the ground.
They lift her, discover the constricting lace, cut it, and Snowdrop soon begins to breathe and revives.
The dwarfs then identify the old woman as the queen herself and warn Snowdrop again not to let anyone in when they are absent.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence:

‘Tell me, glass, tell me true!
  Of all the ladies in the land,
  Who is fairest, tell me, who?’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they said, ‘The old woman was the queen herself; take care another time, and let no one in when we are away.’

events.text_segment:
But the queen, now that she thought Snowdrop was dead, believed that she must be the handsomest lady in the land; and she went to her glass and said:
‘Tell me, glass, tell me true!
  Of all the ladies in the land,
  Who is fairest, tell me, who?’
And the glass answered:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest in all this land:
  But over the hills, in the greenwood shade,
  Where the seven dwarfs their dwelling have made,
  There Snowdrop is hiding her head; and she
  Is lovelier far, O queen! than thee.’
Then the queen was very much frightened; for she knew that the glass always spoke the truth, and was sure that the servant had betrayed her. And she could not bear to think that anyone lived who was more beautiful than she was; so she dressed herself up as an old pedlar, and went her way over the hills, to the place where the dwarfs dwelt. Then she knocked at the door, and cried, ‘Fine wares to sell!’ Snowdrop looked out at the window, and said, ‘Good day, good woman! what have you to sell?’ ‘Good wares, fine wares,’ said she; ‘laces and bobbins of all colours.’ ‘I will let the old lady in; she seems to be a very good sort of body,’ thought Snowdrop, as she ran down and unbolted the door. ‘Bless me!’ said the old woman, ‘how badly your stays are laced! Let me lace them up with one of my nice new laces.’ Snowdrop did not dream of any mischief; so she stood before the old woman; but she set to work so nimbly, and pulled the lace so tight, that Snowdrop’s breath was stopped, and she fell down as if she were dead. ‘There’s an end to all thy beauty,’ said the spiteful queen, and went away home.
In the evening the seven dwarfs came home; and I need not say how grieved they were to see their faithful Snowdrop stretched out upon the ground, as if she was quite dead. However, they lifted her up, and when they found what ailed her, they cut the lace; and in a little time she began to breathe, and very soon came to life again. Then they said, ‘The old woman was the queen herself; take care another time, and let no one in when we are away.’

events.title: The Queen's Second Murder Attempt: The Poisoned Comb
detailed_summary: Upon her return home, the queen immediately consults her mirror, but to her immense dismay, it repeats that Snowdrop, residing with the dwarfs, is still far lovelier.
The queen's blood runs cold with spite and malice knowing Snowdrop is still alive.
She disguises herself again, this time in a completely different attire, and takes a poisoned comb with her.
When she reaches the dwarfs' cottage, she knocks and calls out her wares.
Snowdrop, however, states she dares not let anyone in.
The queen then tempts her by asking her just to look at her beautiful combs and hands her the poisoned one.
The comb appears so pretty that Snowdrop takes it and puts it in her hair to try it.
The moment the comb touches her head, the potent poison takes effect, and she collapses senseless.
The queen, believing Snowdrop is finally dealt with, departs.
Fortunately, the dwarfs return very early that evening.
Seeing Snowdrop on the ground, they quickly surmise what occurred and soon find the poisoned comb.
Once they remove it, Snowdrop recovers and recounts all that happened.
They warn her once more with great emphasis not to open the door to anyone.

  Is lovelier far, O queen! than thee.’

events.text_segment:
When the queen got home, she went straight to her glass, and spoke to it as before; but to her great grief it still said:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest in all this land:
  But over the hills, in the greenwood shade,
  Where the seven dwarfs their dwelling have made,
  There Snowdrop is hiding her head; and she
  Is lovelier far, O queen! than thee.’
Then the blood ran cold in her heart with spite and malice, to see that Snowdrop still lived; and she dressed herself up again, but in quite another dress from the one she wore before, and took with her a poisoned comb. When she reached the dwarfs’ cottage, she knocked at the door, and cried, ‘Fine wares to sell!’ But Snowdrop said, ‘I dare not let anyone in.’ Then the queen said, ‘Only look at my beautiful combs!’ and gave her the poisoned one. And it looked so pretty, that she took it up and put it into her hair to try it; but the moment it touched her head, the poison was so powerful that she fell down senseless. ‘There you may lie,’ said the queen, and went her way. But by good luck the dwarfs came in very early that evening; and when they saw Snowdrop lying on the ground, they thought what had happened, and soon found the poisoned comb. And when they took it away she got well, and told them all that had passed; and they warned her once more not to open the door to anyone.

events.title: The Queen's Third Murder Attempt: The Poisoned Apple
detailed_summary: Meanwhile, the queen returns home to her mirror and shakes with rage upon hearing the same answer as before regarding Snowdrop's superior beauty.
She declares that Snowdrop will die, even if it costs her own life.
She retreats to her chamber alone and prepares a poisoned apple; its exterior looks rosy and tempting, but it is fatal to whoever tastes it.
She then disguises herself as a peasant's wife, travels over the hills to the dwarfs' cottage, and knocks.
Snowdrop puts her head out the window and states she cannot let anyone in because the dwarfs forbade it.
The disguised queen nonchalantly says Snowdrop can do as she pleases but offers her the pretty apple as a gift.
Snowdrop declines, stating she dare not take it.
The old woman calls her silly, questioning her fear and suggesting they share the apple, with each eating a part.
The apple was crafted so that one side was safe while the other was poisoned.
Snowdrop is greatly tempted by the apple's appearance, and when she sees the old woman eat her portion, she can no longer resist.
However, she barely puts the piece into her mouth when she falls down dead on the ground.
The queen triumphantly exclaims that this time nothing will save Snowdrop.
She returns home to her glass, which finally proclaims: ‘Thou, queen, art the fairest of all the fair.’
Her wicked heart is then glad, experiencing as much happiness as such a heart is capable of feeling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meantime the queen went home to her glass, and shook with rage when she read the very same answer as before; and she said, ‘Snowdrop shall die, if it cost me my life.’

events.text_segment:
Meantime the queen went home to her glass, and shook with rage when she read the very same answer as before; and she said, ‘Snowdrop shall die, if it cost me my life.’ So she went by herself into her chamber, and got ready a poisoned apple: the outside looked very rosy and tempting, but whoever tasted it was sure to die. Then she dressed herself up as a peasant’s wife, and travelled over the hills to the dwarfs’ cottage, and knocked at the door; but Snowdrop put her head out of the window and said, ‘I dare not let anyone in, for the dwarfs have told me not.’ ‘Do as you please,’ said the old woman, ‘but at any rate take this pretty apple; I will give it you.’ ‘No,’ said Snowdrop, ‘I dare not take it.’ ‘You silly girl!’ answered the other, ‘what are you afraid of? Do you think it is poisoned? Come! do you eat one part, and I will eat the other.’ Now the apple was so made up that one side was good, though the other side was poisoned. Then Snowdrop was much tempted to taste, for the apple looked so very nice; and when she saw the old woman eat, she could wait no longer. But she had scarcely put the piece into her mouth, when she fell down dead upon the ground. ‘This time nothing will save thee,’ said the queen; and she went home to her glass, and at last it said:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest of all the fair.’
And then her wicked heart was glad, and as happy as such a heart could be.

events.title: Snowdrop's Apparent Death and Vigil in the Glass Coffin
detailed_summary: When evening arrived and the dwarfs returned home, they found Snowdrop lying on the ground; no breath came from her lips, and they feared she was quite dead.
They lifted her, combed her hair, and washed her face with wine and water, but all their efforts were in vain, as the little girl appeared entirely lifeless.
They laid her down upon a bier and all seven watched over and lamented her for three entire days.
After three days, they considered burying her, but her cheeks were still rosy, and her face looked just as it did when she was alive.
Therefore, they decided they would never bury her in the cold ground.
Instead, they constructed a coffin of glass, so they could always look at her, and inscribed upon it in golden letters her name and that she was a king's daughter.
The coffin was set among the hills, and one of the dwarfs always remained by it to watch.
Birds of the air also came to mourn Snowdrop; first an owl, then a raven, and finally a dove, all sat by her side.

events.title: Snowdrop's Revival by the Prince
detailed_summary: Snowdrop lay in this state for a very long time, appearing only as if she were asleep, her complexion still as white as snow, red as blood, and her hair as black as ebony.
At last, a prince came by and called at the dwarfs' house.
He saw Snowdrop in the coffin and read the golden inscription detailing who she was.
He then offered the dwarfs money and earnestly pleaded with them to allow him to take her away.
The dwarfs initially refused, stating they would not part with her for all the gold in the world.
Eventually, however, they felt pity for him and granted his request, giving him the coffin.
The moment his attendants lifted the coffin to carry it home with him, the piece of poisoned apple fell from between Snowdrop's lips.
Snowdrop awoke and asked, ‘Where am I?’
The prince reassured her, saying, ‘Thou art quite safe with me.’

events.text_segment: And thus Snowdrop lay for a long, long time, and still only looked as though she was asleep; for she was even now as white as snow, and as red as blood, and as black as ebony. At last a prince came and called at the dwarfs’ house; and he saw Snowdrop, and read what was written in golden letters. Then he offered the dwarfs money, and prayed and besought them to let him take her away; but they said, ‘We will not part with her for all the gold in the world.’ At last, however, they had pity on him, and gave him the coffin; but the moment he lifted it up to carry it home with him, the piece of apple fell from between her lips, and Snowdrop awoke, and said, ‘Where am I?’ And the prince said, ‘Thou art quite safe with me.’

events.title: Snowdrop's Marriage and the Evil Queen's Final Demise
detailed_summary: The prince then recounted to Snowdrop everything that had occurred.
He declared his love for her, saying he loved her more than anything in the world, and asked her to come with him to his father's palace and become his wife.
Snowdrop consented and accompanied the prince home.
Preparations for their wedding were made with great pomp and splendor.
Among those invited to the feast was Snowdrop's old enemy, the queen.
As the queen was dressing in fine, rich clothes, she looked in her mirror and asked who was the fairest in the land.
The mirror replied that while she, the lady, was lovely, the new-made queen was far lovelier.
Upon hearing this, the queen was startled with rage, but her envy and curiosity were so powerful that she could not resist setting out to see the bride.
When she arrived and saw that the bride was none other than Snowdrop, whom she had long believed to be dead, she choked with rage, fell down, and died.
Snowdrop and the prince, however, lived and reigned happily over that land for many, many years.
Sometimes they would travel to the mountains to visit the little dwarfs who had been so kind to Snowdrop during her time of need.

events.title: The Barren Queen's Wish and the Prophetic Birth
detailed_summary: A queen, saddened by her childlessness, prayed daily for a child.
An angel appeared to her, prophesying that she would have a son endowed with the power to make any wish come true.
The queen shared this joyful news with the king.
In due time, she gave birth to a son, which brought immense happiness to the king.

events.title: The Cook's Deceit, the Child's Abduction, and the Queen's Unjust Imprisonment
detailed_summary: The queen habitually took her young son to a garden with wild animals, where she would bathe in a clear stream.
During one such visit, while the queen slept with the child in her arms, the old cook, aware of the child's wish-granting ability, abducted him.
To frame the queen, the cook slaughtered a hen and stained her apron and dress with its blood.
He then falsely reported to the king that wild beasts had snatched the child.
The king, convinced by the blood evidence, reacted with fury, ordering the queen to be imprisoned in a high, dark tower for seven years without food or water, expecting her to perish.
However, two angels, appearing as white doves, miraculously delivered food to the queen twice a day, sustaining her throughout her seven-year confinement.

Then came the old cook, who knew that the child had the power of wishing, and stole it away, and he took a hen, and cut it in pieces, and dropped some of its blood on the queen’s apron and on her dress. Then he carried the child away to a secret place, where a nurse was obliged to suckle it, and he ran to the king and accused the queen of having allowed her child to be taken from her by the wild beasts. When the king saw the blood on her apron, he believed this, fell into such a passion that he ordered a high tower to be built, in which neither sun nor moon could be seen and had his wife put into it, and walled up. Here she was to stay for seven years without meat or drink, and die of hunger. But God sent two angels from heaven in the shape of white doves, which flew to her twice a day, and carried her food until the seven years were over.

events.title: The Cook's Exploitation, the Maiden's Mercy, and the Cook's Canine Transformation
detailed_summary: The cook, fearing the child's wishing power could expose his villainy, departed from the palace.
He located the boy, who was now old enough to speak, and prompted him to wish for a magnificent palace with a garden, which instantly materialized.
Sometime later, the cook suggested the boy wish for a beautiful girl as a companion, leading to the immediate appearance of a lovely maiden.
The boy and the maiden developed a close bond, playing together and loving each other, while the old cook enjoyed a life of leisure, hunting like a nobleman.
Concerned that the prince might eventually wish to reunite with his father, thus putting the cook in danger, the cook devised a plan.
He privately instructed the maiden to kill the sleeping boy that night by plunging a knife into his heart and to bring him the boy's heart and tongue, threatening her life if she failed.
The next day, when the cook returned, the maiden had not complied, questioning why she should harm an innocent boy.
The cook reiterated his threat, stating her life depended on obedience.
After the cook left, the maiden had a young deer (hind) killed, took its heart and tongue, and placed them on a plate to deceive him.
She instructed the boy to feign sleep in his bed, covered by clothes.
When the cook entered and demanded the boy's heart and tongue, the maiden presented the plate, but the prince suddenly threw off his covers.

The prince confronted the cook, questioning his murderous intent, and then pronounced his sentence: the cook would transform into a black poodle with a gold collar and be forced to eat burning coals until flames erupted from his throat.
Upon these words, the cook was instantly changed into a poodle and compelled by other cooks to eat live coals until his throat burst into flames.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The cook, however, thought to himself: ‘If the child has the power of wishing, and I am here, he might very easily get me into trouble.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And when he had spoken these words, the old man was changed into a poodle dog, and had a gold collar round his neck, and the cooks were ordered to bring up some live coals, and these he ate, until the flames broke forth from his throat.

events.text_segment: The cook, however, thought to himself: ‘If the child has the power of wishing, and I am here, he might very easily get me into trouble.’ So he left the palace and went to the boy, who was already big enough to speak, and said to him: ‘Wish for a beautiful palace for yourself with a garden, and all else that pertains to it.’ Scarcely were the words out of the boy’s mouth, when everything was there that he had wished for. After a while the cook said to him: ‘It is not well for you to be so alone, wish for a pretty girl as a companion.’ Then the king’s son wished for one, and she immediately stood before him, and was more beautiful than any painter could have painted her. The two played together, and loved each other with all their hearts, and the old cook went out hunting like a nobleman. The thought occurred to him, however, that the king’s son might some day wish to be with his father, and thus bring him into great peril. So he went out and took the maiden aside, and said: ‘Tonight when the boy is asleep, go to his bed and plunge this knife into his heart, and bring me his heart and tongue, and if you do not do it, you shall lose your life.’ Thereupon he went away, and when he returned next day she had not done it, and said: ‘Why should I shed the blood of an innocent boy who has never harmed anyone?’ The cook once more said: ‘If you do not do it, it shall cost you your own life.’ When he had gone away, she had a little hind brought to her, and ordered her to be killed, and took her heart and tongue, and laid them on a plate, and when she saw the old man coming, she said to the boy: ‘Lie down in your bed, and draw the clothes over you.’ Then the wicked wretch came in and said: ‘Where are the boy’s heart and tongue?’ The girl reached the plate to him, but the king’s son threw off the quilt, and said: ‘You old sinner, why did you want to kill me? Now will I pronounce thy sentence. You shall become a black poodle and have a gold collar round your neck, and shall eat burning coals, till the flames burst forth from your throat.’ And when he had spoken these words, the old man was changed into a poodle dog, and had a gold collar round his neck, and the cooks were ordered to bring up some live coals, and these he ate, until the flames broke forth from his throat.

events.title: The Prince's Journey Home and Miraculous Reunion at the Tower
detailed_summary: The prince, after some time, began to think of his mother and wondered about her fate.
He decided to return to his homeland and invited the maiden to join him, offering to provide for her.
The maiden expressed reluctance due to the long journey and the prospect of being a stranger in a foreign land.
Unwilling to be separated, the prince wished for her to become a beautiful pink flower, which he then carried with him.
He journeyed back to his country, with the poodle (the transformed cook) following him.
Upon reaching the tower where his mother was imprisoned, he found it very tall and wished for a ladder to reach the top.
He ascended the ladder, looked inside, and called out to his mother, inquiring if she was still alive.
She replied that she had just eaten and was satisfied, believing it was the angels who brought her sustenance.
The prince then revealed his identity, stating he was her son, falsely reported as torn apart by wild beasts, but was alive and would soon liberate her.

At length he said to the maiden: ‘I will go home to my own country; if you will go with me, I will provide for you.’ ‘Ah,’ she replied, ‘the way is so long, and what shall I do in a strange land where I am unknown?’ As she did not seem quite willing, and as they could not be parted from each other, he wished that she might be changed into a beautiful pink, and took her with him. Then he went away to his own country, and the poodle had to run after him. He went to the tower in which his mother was confined, and as it was so high, he wished for a ladder which would reach up to the very top. Then he mounted up and looked inside, and cried: ‘Beloved mother, Lady Queen, are you still alive, or are you dead?’ She answered: ‘I have just eaten, and am still satisfied,’ for she thought the angels were there. Said he: ‘I am your dear son, whom the wild beasts were said to have torn from your arms; but I am alive still, and will soon set you free.’

events.title: The Prince's Guise as a Huntsman and a Miraculous Hunt
detailed_summary: After speaking with his mother, the prince descended from the tower and went to his father, the king.
He had himself announced as a foreign huntsman seeking employment.
The king agreed to hire him if he was skillful and could provide game, mentioning the long-standing scarcity of deer in the area.
The prince confidently promised to procure an abundant supply of game for the royal table.
He then gathered all the royal huntsmen and led them into the forest.
He instructed them to form a large circle, open at one end where he stood, and then he made a wish.
Instantly, more than two hundred deer ran into the circle, where they were shot by the huntsmen.
The massive haul of game was loaded onto sixty carts and transported back to the king.
This allowed the king, after many years, to finally serve game at his table.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then he descended again, and went to his father, and caused himself to be announced as a strange huntsman, and asked if he could offer him service.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they were all placed on sixty country carts, and driven home to the king, and for once he was able to deck his table with game, after having had none at all for years.

events.text_segment: Then he descended again, and went to his father, and caused himself to be announced as a strange huntsman, and asked if he could offer him service. The king said yes, if he was skilful and could get game for him, he should come to him, but that deer had never taken up their quarters in any part of the district or country. Then the huntsman promised to procure as much game for him as he could possibly use at the royal table. So he summoned all the huntsmen together, and bade them go out into the forest with him. And he went with them and made them form a great circle, open at one end where he stationed himself, and began to wish. Two hundred deer and more came running inside the circle at once, and the huntsmen shot them. Then they were all placed on sixty country carts, and driven home to the king, and for once he was able to deck his table with game, after having had none at all for years.

events.title: The Royal Feast, the Prince's Revelation, and the Cook's Exposure
detailed_summary: Delighted by the successful hunt, the king commanded a great feast for his entire household the next day.
During the feast, he insisted that the skilled huntsman (the prince in disguise) sit beside him, despite the huntsman's modest protests.
While seated, the prince wished for one of the king's principal servants to bring up the subject of his mother in the tower.
As soon as he made the wish, the marshal spoke up, asking about the queen's condition and whether she was still alive.
The king angrily retorted that she had allowed his son to be killed by wild beasts and forbade any mention of her.
At this, the huntsman rose and revealed his true identity as the king's son.
He clarified that he was not taken by wild beasts but abducted by the treacherous old cook, who had framed the queen using chicken blood.
He then presented the dog with the golden collar, identifying it as the cook, and had live coals brought for the dog to eat in front of everyone until flames erupted from its throat.
The prince then asked the king if he wished to see the cook in his true form, and with a wish, restored the cook to his human appearance, complete with his white apron and knife.
The king, enraged upon seeing the cook, ordered him to be cast into the deepest dungeon.
The prince further spoke of the maiden who had cared for him and had refused to murder him despite threats to her own life.
He first revealed her to the king as a beautiful flower from his pocket, which he placed on the royal table.
Then, he wished her back into her human form, and she appeared before them, exceptionally beautiful.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now the king felt great joy at this, and commanded that his entire household should eat with him next day, and made a great feast.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the son said: ‘Now will I show her to you in her own form,’ and wished that she might become a maiden, and she stood there looking so beautiful that no painter could have made her look more so.

events.text_segment: Now the king felt great joy at this, and commanded that his entire household should eat with him next day, and made a great feast. When they were all assembled together, he said to the huntsman: ‘As you are so clever, you shall sit by me.’ He replied: ‘Lord King, your majesty must excuse me, I am a poor huntsman.’ But the king insisted on it, and said: ‘You shall sit by me,’ until he did it. Whilst he was sitting there, he thought of his dearest mother, and wished that one of the king’s principal servants would begin to speak of her, and would ask how it was faring with the queen in the tower, and if she were alive still, or had perished. Hardly had he formed the wish than the marshal began, and said: ‘Your majesty, we live joyously here, but how is the queen living in the tower? Is she still alive, or has she died?’ But the king replied: ‘She let my dear son be torn to pieces by wild beasts; I will not have her named.’ Then the huntsman arose and said: ‘Gracious lord father she is alive still, and I am her son, and I was not carried away by wild beasts, but by that wretch the old cook, who tore me from her arms when she was asleep, and sprinkled her apron with the blood of a chicken.’ Thereupon he took the dog with the golden collar, and said: ‘That is the wretch!’ and caused live coals to be brought, and these the dog was compelled to devour before the sight of all, until flames burst forth from its throat. On this the huntsman asked the king if he would like to see the dog in his true shape, and wished him back into the form of the cook, in which he stood immediately, with his white apron, and his knife by his side. When the king saw him he fell into a passion, and ordered him to be cast into the deepest dungeon. Then the huntsman spoke further and said: ‘Father, will you see the maiden who brought me up so tenderly and who was afterwards to murder me, but did not do it, though her own life depended on it?’ The king replied: ‘Yes, I would like to see her.’ The son said: ‘Most gracious father, I will show her to you in the form of a beautiful flower,’ and he thrust his hand into his pocket and brought forth the pink, and placed it on the royal table, and it was so beautiful that the king had never seen one to equal it. Then the son said: ‘Now will I show her to you in her own form,’ and wished that she might become a maiden, and she stood there looking so beautiful that no painter could have made her look more so.

events.title: The Queen's Release and Tragic Death, Final Justice, and the Prince's New Life
detailed_summary: The king sent servants to the tower to retrieve the queen and bring her to the royal table.
When the queen was brought in, she refused to eat, declaring that the merciful God who had sustained her in the tower would soon grant her ultimate freedom.
She lived for only three more days before dying peacefully.
At her burial, the two white doves, recognized as angels from heaven who had provided her food, followed her body and settled on her grave.
The aged king ordered that the cook be executed by being torn into four pieces.
However, grief over these events consumed the king's heart, and he died soon after.
The prince married the beautiful maiden whom he had carried with him as a flower.
The narrator concludes that whether they are still alive is a matter known only to God.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And the king sent two waiting-maids and two attendants into the tower, to fetch the queen and bring her to the royal table.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His son married the beautiful maiden whom he had brought with him as a flower in his pocket, and whether they are still alive or not, is known to God.

events.text_segment: And the king sent two waiting-maids and two attendants into the tower, to fetch the queen and bring her to the royal table. But when she was led in she ate nothing, and said: ‘The gracious and merciful God who has supported me in the tower, will soon set me free.’ She lived three days more, and then died happily, and when she was buried, the two white doves which had brought her food to the tower, and were angels of heaven, followed her body and seated themselves on her grave. The aged king ordered the cook to be torn in four pieces, but grief consumed the king’s own heart, and he soon died. His son married the beautiful maiden whom he had brought with him as a flower in his pocket, and whether they are still alive or not, is known to God.

events.title: Elsie's Betrothal and an Ominous Vision in the Cellar
detailed_summary: - Elsie's parents expressed their desire for her to get married.
- A suitor named Hans appeared, specifying that his future wife, Elsie, must be exceptionally intelligent.
- Elsie's father asserted her good sense, while her mother made hyperbolic claims about her perceptive abilities, such as detecting wind and hearing flies cough.
- Hans reiterated that he would only marry her if she was truly smart.
- During dinner, Elsie was instructed by her mother to go to the cellar to fetch beer.
- Elsie took a pitcher and, to make the time pass quickly, tapped the lid as she descended.
- In the cellar, she arranged a chair by the barrel to avoid straining herself while drawing the beer.
- As the beer flowed, she scanned her surroundings and noticed a pick-axe left precariously above her by masons.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she placed the can before her, and turned the tap, and while the beer was running she would not let her eyes be idle, but looked up at the wall, and after much peering here and there, saw a pick-axe exactly above her, which the masons had accidentally left there.

events.text_segment: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie. And when she had grown up her father said: ‘We will get her married.’ ‘Yes,’ said the mother, ‘if only someone would come who would have her.’ At length a man came from a distance and wooed her, who was called Hans; but he stipulated that Clever Elsie should be really smart. ‘Oh,’ said the father, ‘she has plenty of good sense’; and the mother said: ‘Oh, she can see the wind coming up the street, and hear the flies coughing.’ ‘Well,’ said Hans, ‘if she is not really smart, I won’t have her.’ When they were sitting at dinner and had eaten, the mother said: ‘Elsie, go into the cellar and fetch some beer.’ Then Clever Elsie took the pitcher from the wall, went into the cellar, and tapped the lid briskly as she went, so that the time might not appear long. When she was below she fetched herself a chair, and set it before the barrel so that she had no need to stoop, and did not hurt her back or do herself any unexpected injury. Then she placed the can before her, and turned the tap, and while the beer was running she would not let her eyes be idle, but looked up at the wall, and after much peering here and there, saw a pick-axe exactly above her, which the masons had accidentally left there.
